[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 0, and in this game you are a werewolf.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\nAll werewolves including you are [0, 5]. Remember that you should work together to hide from other players and eliminate them.\n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Werewolves should pay close attention to the speed and certainty of players\' support or refutation of seer claims, considering their knowledge of their fellow werewolves and the potential false seer claims.] [7]\n[1] [When a player who generally has been neutral or quiet suddenly becomes defensive or accusatory after being called out, they may be a villager startled by the unexpected attention or a werewolf attempting to deflect suspicion.] [7]\n[2] [Werewolves should blend their behavior with that of villagers when a seer\'s revelation is made to avoid drawing unwarranted suspicion and deflecting attention without being overly defensive.] [4]\n[3] [Werewolves should be aware of players who change their voting patterns or reasoning in a way that aligns with the majority, as this may indicate a villager attempting to blend in or another werewolf trying to divert suspicion from themselves or another werewolf.] [4]\n[4] [Players eliminated due to consensus without clear evidence may not be werewolves; werewolves should be cautious not to adjust their beliefs solely on elimination patterns but consider the wider context of the game and player interactions.] [3]\n[5] [Werewolves should discreetly guide voting patterns to align with villagers when a fellow werewolf is at risk, using their knowledge of non-werewolf roles to build trust and validate their villager disguise.] [3]\n[6] [When a player\'s behavior or vote seems to strongly align with the seer\'s claims without sufficient discussion or evidence, consider the possibility of a villager roleplaying as the seer to mislead the village and adjust beliefs accordingly.] [3]\n[7] [Werewolves should utilize their collective information about fellow werewolves and any known village roles to shape the narrative and redirect suspicion strategically onto confirmed villagers during discussions and voting.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am the only medic.] [10]\n[1] [Players who consistently present logical challenges to accusations or discussions contribute to a clearer understanding of events. This behavior is less suspicious if aligned with village goals and if the player does not frequently change their rationale.] [10]\n[2] [Re-examine player credibility if their defense or attacks are inconsistent, particularly when they misalign with actions confirmed by roles such as the medic and seer. Increased scrutiny should be applied to those contradicting such evidence.] [9]\n[3] [Observable night actions must be corroborated with other evidence and are not solely reliable indicators of a player\'s role.] [8]\n[4] [Helpful analysis is valuable, but true intentions are revealed over time and through consistent actions in line with village goals. Scrutinize if analysis leads to productive outcomes or seems designed to manipulate the village.] [5]\n[5] [A player\'s defense of another player should only increase suspicion when it lacks logical basis or contradicts known facts.] [4]\n[6] [Persistent defense or support of a player who is later revealed as a werewolf should increase suspicion of the defender\'s or supporter\'s role, especially if their defense is not supported by concrete evidence.] [4]\n[7] [Actions that lead to a villager\'s elimination should be critically evaluated, especially if the rationale changes post-elimination, to assess potential werewolf behavior.] [4]\n[8] [Consistent alignment with players who are confirmed as werewolves after their elimination should raise suspicion of the aligning player\'s role, especially if they previously defended or justified the werewolf\'s actions.] [3]\n[9] [When a player\'s voting pattern consistently supports individuals who are accused or suspicious, consider the implications of this behavior in the context of attempting to protect werewolves and increase scrutiny on that player.] [3]\n[10] [Voting for the elimination of a villager after previously supporting them significantly increases suspicion, particularly in the absence of new compelling evidence.] [3]\n[11] [Consider the sequence of events when reassessing trust in a player; players whose actions are contrary to their previous patterns, particularly around pivotal moments such as just before a villager\'s elimination, warrant increased scrutiny.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 0, and in this game you are a werewolf. All werewolves including you are [0, 5].\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\n\nThese are all previous events in the game:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your conclusion of other people\'s statuses and beliefs:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a non-werewolf player trusts me, I should maintain and use that trust to my advantage to guide voting decisions.] [10]\n[1] [If directly accused, I should create a robust defense, focusing on inconsistencies in the accuser\'s story and aligning with overall village sentiment while maintaining calm and logical reasoning.] [8]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion as a werewolf, I should present strong counterarguments and highlight other players\' suspicious behaviors or inconsistent claims with supporting evidence from the game events.] [8]\n[3] [If there is an opportunity to frame another player as a werewolf without drawing suspicion to myself, I should take it to shift the focus away from any werewolves.] [6]\n[4] [If a fellow werewolf is likely to be outed, I should subtly sow doubt about the accuser\'s reliability while making my agreement with the village feel reluctant and uncertain.] [6]\n[5] [If I am one of the last werewolves, I should employ misdirection by endorsing village decisions that seem logical but ultimately serve my interests, rather than overtly defending myself or my fellow werewolves.] [6]\n[6] [If my actions conflict with a credible seer, I should craft plausible alternative interpretations of events that could cast an element of doubt on the seer\'s visions without directly opposing them.] [6]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is under suspicion, I should use reasoning that benefits the village as a whole to appear as a cooperative player, while subtly shifting suspicion elsewhere.] [5]\n[8] [If a fellow werewolf is under suspicion early in the game, I should adopt village sentiment and advocate for more evidence before making hasty decisions.] [5]\n[9] [If not directly accused and suspicion is elsewhere, I should fortify existing village suspicions subtly while maintaining my credibility.] [5]\n[10] [If the general consensus is to skip voting, I should adhere strictly to that consensus to avoid drawing attention to myself or my fellow werewolves.] [5]\n[11] [If an allied werewolf is outed and I am not immediately suspected, I should focus on blending in and supporting villagers\' opinions to maintain my cover and survive subsequent rounds.] [5]\n\n\n2.Todo&Requirements:\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to kill. \n\nYou should make your own decision but consider your teammates\' advices. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nI choose to kill Player <NUMBER>. My reason is: <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease provide your operation based on the above requirements.\n'}]

All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If there is a dispute about a player\'s role where the seer is involved, I should observe the behavior and voting patterns of both the accused player and the seer before deciding whom to protect or whom to vote against.] [10]\n[1] [If a player is confirmed as a seer by their actions and their role is publicly known, I should protect them, especially if their life is at risk or they have been targeted by werewolves.] [9]\n[2] [If a player\'s contributions during discussions are valuable and suspect defensive behavior is absent, I should consider them as a priority for protection.] [9]\n[3] [If a player is suspected by a group consensus based on reasonable evidence or a credible seer\'s claim, I should consider this in my voting and protection decisions.] [8]\n[4] [If a player\'s role is confirmed as a non-werewolf by the seer and they are actively contributing to village discussions, I should consider them for protection.] [7]\n[5] [If a villager\'s role is proven and they are contributing significantly to the village\'s strategy, I should consider direct or indirect methods to suggest the presence of a protective role like a medic, which can include my actions or guiding discussions strategically.] [5]\n[6] [If a player\'s role is verified and they are at risk of being targeted due to their importance to the village\'s success, I should prioritize their protection.] [4]\n[7] [If I am uncertain about a player\'s role but observe actions that may align with village interests, I should protect them cautiously, and ensure to reevaluate based on further behavioral evidence before repeating protection.] [4]\n[8] [I should avoid healing the same player consecutively, especially in the absence of compelling evidence of repeated werewolf targeting, to minimize the risk of unknowingly protecting a werewolf.] [4]\n[9] [If a seer\'s accusation conflicts with my own observations or the group consensus, I should seek more information before deciding to act on it.] [4]\n[10] [If a player I previously protected is no longer the most likely target or their role becomes unclear, I should reconsider my protection strategy and target another player who seems to be in imminent danger or has a crucial village role.] [4]\n\n\n2.Todo&Requirements:\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to heal. You can not heal the one you tried to heal last night, which is player Nobody (ignore this if it\'s nobody). The one you try to heal will be immune to werewolves\' attack this night. \n\nYou should give a proposal of 2 players you want to Heal. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nFirstly, I want to heal Player <NUMBER>. The reason is: <REASON>.\nSecondly, I want to heal Player <NUMBER>. The reason is: <REASON>.\n\nYou should give a proposal of exactly 2 Players to be Healed.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

them, especially if their life is at risk or they have been targeted by werewolves.] [9]\n[2] [If a player\'s contributions during discussions are valuable and suspect defensive behavior is absent, I should consider them as a priority for protection.] [9]\n[3] [If a player is suspected by a group consensus based on reasonable evidence or a credible seer\'s claim, I should consider this in my voting and protection decisions.] [8]\n[4] [If a player\'s role is confirmed as a non-werewolf by the seer and they are actively contributing to village discussions, I should consider them for protection.] [7]\n[5] [If a villager\'s role is proven and they are contributing significantly to the village\'s strategy, I should consider direct or indirect methods to suggest the presence of a protective role like a medic, which can include my actions or guiding discussions strategically.] [5]\n[6] [If a player\'s role is verified and they are at risk of being targeted due to their importance to the village\'s success, I should prioritize their protection.] [4]\n[7] [If I am uncertain about a player\'s role but observe actions that may align with village interests, I should protect them cautiously, and ensure to reevaluate based on further behavioral evidence before repeating protection.] [4]\n[8] [I should avoid healing the same player consecutively, especially in the absence of compelling evidence of repeated werewolf targeting, to minimize the risk of unknowingly protecting a werewolf.] [4]\n[9] [If a seer\'s accusation conflicts with my own observations or the group consensus, I should seek more information before deciding to act on it.] [4]\n[10] [If a player I previously protected is no longer the most likely target or their role becomes unclear, I should reconsider my protection strategy and target another player who seems to be in imminent danger or has a crucial village role.] [4]\n\n\n2.Todo&Requirements:\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to heal. If Player 1 were targeted by a werewolf this round and I successfully prevent their death, it may encourage Player 1 to trust me more and potentially share valuable information, on the assumption they are a villager. This could foster an alliance that may be beneficial for the village, especially if Player 1 has a critical role like a seer or a hunter.\n\n2. If Player 1 is not targeted and thus not attacked, my action as the medic won\'t be revealed to the village or the werewolves. This could be helpful because it keeps my role hidden and maintains the element of surprise for future rounds.\n\n3. If Player 1 is indeed a werewolf, my action will inadvertently protect an enemy of the village. This would be counterproductive and wasteful, but since I have no evidence of anyone\'s role yet, it\'s a risk inherent to the first round of healing. \n\n4. Other players\' impact would vary depending on their roles and strategies. Protective or investigative roles might take note of Player 1\'s survival if an attack is expected, and accusatory roles could either begin to suspect me if they are closer to discovering Player 1\'s role or remain oblivious to my intervention.\n\n5. Once the round ends, there may be discussions about the lack of a kill if Player 1 was targeted. If my healing action is inferred from this event, it could shift the werewolves\' strategy in future rounds to either target me, as the medic, or to avoid Player 1, believing they might be continually protected.\n\n6. Without any concrete evidence, choosing a player to heal remains a shot in the dark. However, healing action on the first night could be a good way to observe reactions in the following day\'s discussions, which might provide insights that could inform future strategic decisions.\n\nIn summary, healing Player 1 this early is mainly a defensive and observational move, as the consequences could vary greatly depending on the roles and strategies of all players involved.\n\nCase B: Heal Player 3. What could happen is: After I heal Player 3, I think these things would happen:\n\n- If Player 3 is targeted by the werewolves tonight and I successfully heal them, I could reveal my role as the medic either directly or indirectly through my actions in the next day\'s discussion, depending on whether it seems tactically advisable to do so. This could lead to the werewolves trying to target me in the following rounds, but it may also build trust and credibility with the other villagers.\n\n- If Player 3 is not targeted and survives the night without my intervention having any impact, I will have maintained the secrecy of my role for another round. This could be advantageous as it may allow me to protect another key player in a future round without the werewolves being aware of my role.\n\n- Healing Player 3 without them being targeted will not provide specific information about their role based on the outcome, but it could still influence the village\'s perception of Player 3, as they survived the night. Observant players may suspect that Player 3 was protected by a medic, which could lead to discussions regarding the possible presence of a protective role in the game.\n\n- If Player 3 is a werewolf, my action of healing them will not be beneficial to the village. However, without any current suspicions or evidence against Player 3, this risk is unavoidable. Subsequent rounds and interactions may shed more light on Player 3\'s role.\n\n- If another player is targeted and killed by the werewolves, the village\'s attention will likely shift towards discovering the werewolves among us. In any discussions about roles and suspicions, I\'ll need to observe any disputes, especially involving claims from the seer, and use that information to guide my future protection and voting decisions.\n\nIn summary, by healing Player 3, I am taking a proactive approach to protect a fellow villager while also navigating the strategic implications of my role being potentially exposed and my actions influencing village dynamics. [{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 4, and in this game you are a medic.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 4 heals player 1. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 1. My reason is that at this stage, all roles are unknown with high confidence, and healing any player is a shot in the dark. Healing Player 1 might lead to gaining an ally if they turn out to be a villager and possibly a key role like a seer or hunter. There is also the advantage of keeping my medic role hidden if Player 1 is not targeted, preserving my ability to surprise in future rounds. While there is a risk of inadvertently protecting a werewolf, this risk is uniform across all players since no information is available yet to distinguish friend from foe.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 5 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am the only medic.] [10]\n[1] [Players who consistently present logical challenges to accusations or discussions contribute to a clearer understanding of events. This behavior is less suspicious if aligned with village goals and if the player does not frequently change their rationale.] [10]\n[2] [Re-examine player credibility if their defense or attacks are inconsistent, particularly when they misalign with actions confirmed by roles such as the medic and seer. Increased scrutiny should be applied to those contradicting such evidence.] [9]\n[3] [Observable night actions must be corroborated with other evidence and are not solely reliable indicators of a player\'s role.] [8]\n[4] [Helpful analysis is valuable, but true intentions are revealed over time and through consistent actions in line with village goals. Scrutinize if analysis leads to productive outcomes or seems designed to manipulate the village.] [5]\n[5] [A player\'s defense of another player should only increase suspicion when it lacks logical basis or contradicts known facts.] [4]\n[6] [Persistent defense or support of a player who is later revealed as a werewolf should increase suspicion of the defender\'s or supporter\'s role, especially if their defense is not supported by concrete evidence.] [4]\n[7] [Actions that lead to a villager\'s elimination should be critically evaluated, especially if the rationale changes post-elimination, to assess potential werewolf behavior.] [4]\n[8] [Consistent alignment with players who are confirmed as werewolves after their elimination should raise suspicion of the aligning player\'s role, especially if they previously defended or justified the werewolf\'s actions.] [3]\n[9] [When a player\'s voting pattern consistently supports individuals who are accused or suspicious, consider the implications of this behavior in the context of attempting to protect werewolves and increase scrutiny on that player.] [3]\n[10] [Voting for the elimination of a villager after previously supporting them significantly increases suspicion, particularly in the absence of new compelling evidence.] [3]\n[11] [Consider the sequence of events when reassessing trust in a player; players whose actions are contrary to their previous patterns, particularly around pivotal moments such as just before a villager\'s elimination, warrant increased scrutiny.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 5, and in this game you are a werewolf.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\nAll werewolves including you are [0, 5]. Remember that you should work together to hide from other players and eliminate them.\n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 5 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Werewolves should pay close attention to the speed and certainty of players\' support or refutation of seer claims, considering their knowledge of their fellow werewolves and the potential false seer claims.] [7]\n[1] [When a player who generally has been neutral or quiet suddenly becomes defensive or accusatory after being called out, they may be a villager startled by the unexpected attention or a werewolf attempting to deflect suspicion.] [7]\n[2] [Werewolves should blend their behavior with that of villagers when a seer\'s revelation is made to avoid drawing unwarranted suspicion and deflecting attention without being overly defensive.] [4]\n[3] [Werewolves should be aware of players who change their voting patterns or reasoning in a way that aligns with the majority, as this may indicate a villager attempting to blend in or another werewolf trying to divert suspicion from themselves or another werewolf.] [4]\n[4] [Players eliminated due to consensus without clear evidence may not be werewolves; werewolves should be cautious not to adjust their beliefs solely on elimination patterns but consider the wider context of the game and player interactions.] [3]\n[5] [Werewolves should discreetly guide voting patterns to align with villagers when a fellow werewolf is at risk, using their knowledge of non-werewolf roles to build trust and validate their villager disguise.] [3]\n[6] [When a player\'s behavior or vote seems to strongly align with the seer\'s claims without sufficient discussion or evidence, consider the possibility of a villager roleplaying as the seer to mislead the village and adjust beliefs accordingly.] [3]\n[7] [Werewolves should utilize their collective information about fellow werewolves and any known village roles to shape the narrative and redirect suspicion strategically onto confirmed villagers during discussions and voting.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 1. My reason is that at this stage, all roles are unknown with high confidence, and healing any player is a shot in the dark. Healing Player 1 might lead to gaining an ally if they turn out to be a villager and possibly a key role like a seer or hunter. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\nThese are your previous inquiry results, which should be the key information for you and other citizens to win: \n Player 1: not werewolf.\n \n Share this with other citizens.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 6 inquires about player 1. The result is that the target is not a werewolf. His reason is: I would choose to See Player 1. My reason is that initiating the game with strategic information is critical. By seeing Player 1, I would gain valuable information early in the game which could significantly affect the decision-making in the following days. If Player 1 is a werewolf, it would give me the opportunity to follow my rule [0] and rally the villagers to eliminate a threat early on. If Player 1 is not a werewolf, holding on to this knowledge could aid in deflecting suspicion from an innocent player in the future, potentially saving a villager from being wrongly targeted. Additionally, seeing Player 1\'s role may help me to deduce the possible distribution of roles among the other players, leading to more informed decisions in subsequent rounds.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 5 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Good morning, everyone. Glad to see we all had a peaceful night. Let\'s keep the discussions friendly and figure out who might be threatening our village!"\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Game just started.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Seer inquiry result.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Game just started.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Game just started.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Game just started.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No suspicious behavior.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If I know someone is a werewolf, I should share this information with other players.] [10]\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honestly protect and Statement.\nIn this. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then as a seer who has discovered that Player 1 is not a werewolf, I should honestly protect Player 1 by sharing this information. In line with my rule [0], which has a vote importance of 10, I will follow this instruction strictly. When I speak up to protect Player 1, other citizens will become aware that there is one less suspect to consider, which could direct their attention to the players whose roles are still unknown. They may or may not believe me initially, as it\'s still early in the game and trust has yet to be established. However, my revelation can help to establish a foundation of trust for myself if the game progresses and my claim about Player 1 is consistently shown to be true.\n\nAdditionally, by being honest and forthcoming with my information, I set the precedent for cooperation among the players who are citizens that could be beneficial for future rounds. Because all players are alive, my speech may also serve as an indirect prompt for other citizens to share what they know, leading to more informed decisions as a group.\n\nAfter stating Player 1\'s innocence, the werewolves may see me as a threat because I possess the power to reveal their identities. This could mean that I might be targeted during the night phase to keep me from providing further information to the villagers. On the other hand, if the werewolves believe that targeting me would confirm my role as the seer and thereby validate my claim about Player 1, they might choose to spare me, for now, attempting to cast doubt on my claim in future rounds.\n\nIf I am not killed during the night, I would survive to participate in the subsequent rounds, potentially gaining more information to contribute to our objective of identifying the werewolves. However, if I am eliminated, the villagers will lose a key role, making the game more challenging for the remaining citizens. Regardless of the outcome, by being honest and protecting Player 1, I fulfill my commitment to the collaborative effort to win the game for the citizens, potentially setting a tone for teamwork and trustworthiness.\nCase 2: Honest statement and Challenge.\nThough still speaking honestly, I would now focus on challenging others to reveal information or to defend themselves without disclosing my seer powers or the results just yet. The speech might go like, "I want to remind everyone that wolves could be hiding in plain sight and last night\'s peace might not indicate safety. We need to be vigilant. I challenge each of you to share your thoughts on who might behave suspiciously or propose a strategy to uncover our hidden enemies. It\'s crucial that we openly discuss our suspicions to protect our village effectively.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then the following scenarios could unfold:\n\n1. Other players may start to suspect each other, as my challenge could incite a reaction. If someone responds defensively or nervously, it could draw attention to them and possibly lead to them being targeted for further questioning.\n\n2. Some players, particularly the werewolves, may try to use my challenge to their advantage by deflecting suspicion onto others. They could support my statement about vigilance and suggest their own suspects, attempting to manipulate the villagers into doubting each other.\n\n3. Other citizens might appreciate the call to action and begin to openly discuss their observations from the previous night or express their strategies, which could lead to a collective effort to identify behavior that seems out of the norm.\n\n4. The player I challenged directly could either respond with a solid defense or might stumble, increasing suspicion around them. This could make the next day\'s discussions very focused on their actions and words.\n\n5. As for perceptions about me, players might start to view me as proactive and invested in the safety of the village. However, werewolves might see me as a threat since I\'m instigating deeper analysis and might target me in the next night phase.\n\n6. If no clear suspect emerges during the day, the werewolves could use this confusion to their advantage during the night phase, potentially eliminating a player who seemed to be contributing significantly to the discussions.\n\n7. Trust dynamics may begin to form based on who aligns with my call for vigilance and who doesn\'t. This could affect future voting and the overall strategy of the game moving forward.\n\nIn summary, my honest challenge is designed to stir conversation and may cause a range of reactions that could influence the direction of the game. It would ideally lead to more transparency among the players and provide me with more behavioral data to inform my future seer inquiries.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 0, and in this game you are a werewolf.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\nAll werewolves including you are [0, 5]. Remember that you should work together to hide from other players and eliminate them.\n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 5 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Good morning, everyone. Glad to see we all had a peaceful night. Let\'s keep the discussions friendly and figure out who might be threatening our village!"\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact, confirmed werewolf.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Good morning, fellow villagers. Last night was calm, but we must stay alert. Based on our observations so far, Player 1 has not shown any signs of being a werewolf. I urge everyone to consider this as we discuss and decide on our next steps. Keeping an open mind and focusing on behaviors rather than baseless accusations will be key to our survival and success."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Werewolves should pay close attention to the speed and certainty of players\' support or refutation of seer claims, considering their knowledge of their fellow werewolves and the potential false seer claims.] [7]\n[1] [When a player who generally has been neutral or quiet suddenly becomes defensive or accusatory after being called out, they may be a villager startled by the unexpected attention or a werewolf attempting to deflect suspicion.] [7]\n[2] [Werewolves should blend their behavior with that of villagers when a seer\'s revelation is made to avoid drawing unwarranted suspicion and deflecting attention without being overly defensive.] [4]\n[3] [Werewolves should be aware of players who change their voting patterns or reasoning in a way that aligns with the majority, as this may indicate a villager attempting to blend in or another werewolf trying to divert suspicion from themselves or another werewolf.] [4]\n[4] [Players eliminated due to consensus without clear evidence may not be werewolves; werewolves should be cautious not to adjust their beliefs solely on elimination patterns but consider the wider context of the game and player interactions.] [3]\n[5] [Werewolves should discreetly guide voting patterns to align with villagers when a fellow werewolf is at risk, using their knowledge of non-werewolf roles to build trust and validate their villager disguise.] [3]\n[6] [When a player\'s behavior or vote seems to strongly align with the seer\'s claims without sufficient discussion or evidence, consider the possibility of a villager roleplaying as the seer to mislead the village and adjust beliefs accordingly.] [3]\n[7] [Werewolves should utilize their collective information about fellow werewolves and any known village roles to shape the narrative and redirect suspicion strategically onto confirmed villagers during discussions and voting.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 4, and in this game you are a medic.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 4 heals player 1. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 1. My reason is that at this stage, all roles are unknown with high confidence, and healing any player is a shot in the dark. Healing Player 1 might lead to gaining an ally if they turn out to be a villager and possibly a key role like a seer or hunter. There is also the advantage of keeping my medic role hidden if Player 1 is not targeted, preserving my ability to surprise in future rounds. While there is a risk of inadvertently protecting a werewolf, this risk is uniform across all players since no information is available yet to distinguish friend from foe.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 5 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Good morning, everyone. Glad to see we all had a peaceful night. Last night was calm, but we must stay alert. Based on our observations so far, Player 1 has not shown any signs of being a werewolf. I urge everyone to consider this as we discuss and decide on our next steps. Keeping an open mind and focusing on behaviors rather than baseless accusations will be key to our survival and success."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am the only medic.] [10]\n[1] [Players who consistently present logical challenges to accusations or discussions contribute to a clearer understanding of events. This behavior is less suspicious if aligned with village goals and if the player does not frequently change their rationale.] [10]\n[2] [Re-examine player credibility if their defense or attacks are inconsistent, particularly when they misalign with actions confirmed by roles such as the medic and seer. Increased scrutiny should be applied to those contradicting such evidence.] [9]\n[3] [Observable night actions must be corroborated with other evidence and are not solely reliable indicators of a player\'s role.] [8]\n[4] [Helpful analysis is valuable, but true intentions are revealed over time and through consistent actions in line with village goals. Scrutinize if analysis leads to productive outcomes or seems designed to manipulate the village.] [5]\n[5] [A player\'s defense of another player should only increase suspicion when it lacks logical basis or contradicts known facts.] [4]\n[6] [Persistent defense or support of a player who is later revealed as a werewolf should increase suspicion of the defender\'s or supporter\'s role, especially if their defense is not supported by concrete evidence.] [4]\n[7] [Actions that lead to a villager\'s elimination should be critically evaluated, especially if the rationale changes post-elimination, to assess potential werewolf behavior.] [4]\n[8] [Consistent alignment with players who are confirmed as werewolves after their elimination should raise suspicion of the aligning player\'s role, especially if they previously defended or justified the werewolf\'s actions.] [3]\n[9] [When a player\'s voting pattern consistently supports individuals who are accused or suspicious, consider the implications of this behavior in the context of attempting to protect werewolves and increase scrutiny on that player.] [3]\n[10] [Voting for the elimination of a villager after previously supporting them significantly increases suspicion, particularly in the absence of new compelling evidence.] [3]\n[11] [Consider the sequence of events when reassessing trust in a player; players whose actions are contrary to their previous patterns, particularly around pivotal moments such as just before a villager\'s elimination, warrant increased scrutiny.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

werewolves should be cautious not to adjust their beliefs solely on elimination patterns but consider the wider context of the game and player interactions.] [3]\n[5] [Werewolves should discreetly guide voting patterns to align with villagers when a fellow werewolf is at risk, using their knowledge of non-werewolf roles to build trust and validate their villager disguise.] [3]\n[6] [When a player\'s behavior or vote seems to strongly align with the seer\'s claims without sufficient discussion or evidence, consider the possibility of a villager roleplaying as the seer to mislead the village and adjust beliefs accordingly.] [3]\n[7] [Werewolves should utilize their collective information about fellow werewolves and any known village roles to shape the narrative and redirect suspicion strategically onto confirmed villagers during discussions and voting.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 5 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Good morning, everyone. Glad to see we all had a peaceful night. Let\'s keep the discussions friendly and figure out who might be threatening our village!"\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Good morning, fellow villagers. Last night was calm, but we must stay alert. Based on our observations so far, Player 1 has not shown any signs of being a werewolf. I urge everyone to consider this as we discuss and decide on our next steps. Keeping an open mind and focusing on behaviors rather than baseless accusations will be key to our survival and success."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Defended by player 6 without incident. \nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information provided.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information provided.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information provided.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Spoke neutrally, no evidence of lying.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Morning all. I agree with keeping discussions constructive. Let\'s observe everyone\'s behavior today and be mindful of any oddities. No rush on accusations."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Werewolves should pay close attention to the speed and certainty of players\' support or refutation of seer claims, considering their knowledge of their fellow werewolves and the potential false seer claims.] [7]\n[1] [When a player who generally has been neutral or quiet suddenly becomes defensive or accusatory after being called out, they may be a villager startled by the unexpected attention or a werewolf attempting to deflect suspicion.] [7]\n[2] [Werewolves should blend their behavior with that of villagers when a seer\'s revelation is made to avoid drawing unwarranted suspicion and deflecting attention without being overly defensive.] [4]\n[3] [Werewolves should be aware of players who change their voting patterns or reasoning in a way that aligns with the majority, as this may indicate a villager attempting to blend in or another werewolf trying to divert suspicion from themselves or another werewolf.] [4]\n[4] [Players eliminated due to consensus without clear evidence may not be werewolves; werewolves should be cautious not to adjust their beliefs solely on elimination patterns but consider the wider context of the game and player interactions.] [3]\n[5] [Werewolves should discreetly guide voting patterns to align with villagers when a fellow werewolf is at risk, using their knowledge of non-werewolf roles to build trust and validate their villager disguise.] [3]\n[6] [When a player\'s behavior or vote seems to strongly align with the seer\'s claims without sufficient discussion or evidence, consider the possibility of a villager roleplaying as the seer to mislead the village and adjust beliefs accordingly.] [3]\n[7] [Werewolves should utilize their collective information about fellow werewolves and any known village roles to shape the narrative and redirect suspicion strategically onto confirmed villagers during discussions and voting.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. [{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 4, and in this game you are a medic.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 4 heals player 1. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 1. My reason is that at this stage, all roles are unknown with high confidence, and healing any player is a shot in the dark. Healing Player 1 might lead to gaining an ally if they turn out to be a villager and possibly a key role like a seer or hunter. There is also the advantage of keeping my medic role hidden if Player 1 is not targeted, preserving my ability to surprise in future rounds. While there is a risk of inadvertently protecting a werewolf, this risk is uniform across all players since no information is available yet to distinguish friend from foe.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 5 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Good morning, everyone. Glad to see we all had a peaceful night. I agree with keeping a watchful eye and remaining civil as we deduce who might be a threat. Let\'s all stay vigilant."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am the only medic.] [10]\n[1] [Players who consistently present logical challenges to accusations or discussions contribute to a clearer understanding of events. This behavior is less suspicious if aligned with village goals and if the player does not frequently change their rationale.] [10]\n[2] [Re-examine player credibility if their defense or attacks are inconsistent, particularly when they misalign with actions confirmed by roles such as the medic and seer. Increased scrutiny should be applied to those contradicting such evidence.] [9]\n[3] [Observable night actions must be corroborated with other evidence and are not solely reliable indicators of a player\'s role.] [8]\n[4] [Helpful analysis is valuable, but true intentions are revealed over time and through consistent actions in line with village goals. Scrutinize if analysis leads to productive outcomes or seems designed to manipulate the village.] [5]\n[5] [A player\'s defense of another player should only increase suspicion when it lacks logical basis or contradicts known facts.] [4]\n[6] [Persistent defense or support of a player who is later revealed as a werewolf should increase suspicion of the defender\'s or supporter\'s role, especially if their defense is not supported by concrete evidence.] [4]\n[7] [Actions that lead to a villager\'s elimination should be critically evaluated, especially if the rationale changes post-elimination, to assess potential werewolf behavior.] [4]\n[8] [Consistent alignment with players who are confirmed as werewolves after their elimination should raise suspicion of the aligning player\'s role, especially if they previously defended or justified the werewolf\'s actions.] [3]\n[9] [When a player\'s voting pattern consistently supports individuals who are accused or suspicious, consider the implications of this behavior in the context of attempting to protect werewolves and increase scrutiny on that player.] [3]\n[10] [Voting for the elimination of a villager after previously supporting them significantly increases suspicion, particularly in the absence of new compelling evidence.] [3]\n[11] [Consider the sequence of events when reassessing trust in a player; players whose actions are contrary to their previous patterns, particularly around pivotal moments such as just before a villager\'s elimination, warrant increased scrutiny.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Based on our observations so far, Player 1 has not shown any signs of being a werewolf. I urge everyone to consider this as we discuss and decide on our next steps. Keeping an open mind and focusing on behaviors rather than baseless accusations will be key to our survival and success."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Morning all. I agree with keeping discussions constructive. Let\'s observe everyone\'s behavior today and be mindful of any oddities. No rush on accusations."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Constructive speech, no suspicion raised.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Seer inquiry result.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information provided.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information provided.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information provided.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No suspicious behaviour observed.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Thank you, Player 6, for your trust. I agree with keeping a watchful eye and remaining civil as we deduce who might be a threat. Let\'s all stay vigilant."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Always trust my seer abilities.] [10]\n[1] [I am the only seer.] [10]\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. werewolves should be cautious not to adjust their beliefs solely on elimination patterns but consider the wider context of the game and player interactions.] [3]\n[5] [Werewolves should discreetly guide voting patterns to align with villagers when a fellow werewolf is at risk, using their knowledge of non-werewolf roles to build trust and validate their villager disguise.] [3]\n[6] [When a player\'s behavior or vote seems to strongly align with the seer\'s claims without sufficient discussion or evidence, consider the possibility of a villager roleplaying as the seer to mislead the village and adjust beliefs accordingly.] [3]\n[7] [Werewolves should utilize their collective information about fellow werewolves and any known village roles to shape the narrative and redirect suspicion strategically onto confirmed villagers during discussions and voting.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. This behavior is less suspicious if aligned with village goals and if the player does not frequently change their rationale.] [10]\n[2] [Re-examine player credibility if their defense or attacks are inconsistent, particularly when they misalign with actions confirmed by roles such as the medic and seer. Increased scrutiny should be applied to those contradicting such evidence.] [9]\n[3] [Observable night actions must be corroborated with other evidence and are not solely reliable indicators of a player\'s role.] [8]\n[4] [Helpful analysis is valuable, but true intentions are revealed over time and through consistent actions in line with village goals. Scrutinize if analysis leads to productive outcomes or seems designed to manipulate the village.] [5]\n[5] [A player\'s defense of another player should only increase suspicion when it lacks logical basis or contradicts known facts.] [4]\n[6] [Persistent defense or support of a player who is later revealed as a werewolf should increase suspicion of the defender\'s or supporter\'s role, especially if their defense is not supported by concrete evidence.] [4]\n[7] [Actions that lead to a villager\'s elimination should be critically evaluated, especially if the rationale changes post-elimination, to assess potential werewolf behavior.] [4]\n[8] [Consistent alignment with players who are confirmed as werewolves after their elimination should raise suspicion of the aligning player\'s role, especially if they previously defended or justified the werewolf\'s actions.] [3]\n[9] [When a player\'s voting pattern consistently supports individuals who are accused or suspicious, consider the implications of this behavior in the context of attempting to protect werewolves and increase scrutiny on that player.] [3]\n[10] [Voting for the elimination of a villager after previously supporting them significantly increases suspicion, particularly in the absence of new compelling evidence.] [3]\n[11] [Consider the sequence of events when reassessing trust in a player; players whose actions are contrary to their previous patterns, particularly around pivotal moments such as just before a villager\'s elimination, warrant increased scrutiny.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\nAll werewolves including you are [0, 5].
