A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 5 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Good morning, everyone. Glad to see we all had a peaceful night. Let\'s keep the discussions friendly and figure out who might be threatening our village!"\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Good morning, fellow villagers. Last night was calm, but we must stay alert. Based on our observations so far, Player 1 has not shown any signs of being a werewolf. I urge everyone to consider this as we discuss and decide on our next steps. Keeping an open mind and focusing on behaviors rather than baseless accusations will be key to our survival and success."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Morning all. I agree with keeping discussions constructive. Let\'s observe everyone\'s behavior today and be mindful of any oddities. No rush on accusations."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Thank you, Player 6, for your trust. I agree with keeping a watchful eye and remaining civil as we deduce who might be a threat. Let\'s all stay vigilant."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Morning, everyone. I appreciate the peace last night and support attentive, respectful discussion. Let\'s be observant and considerate in our approach to finding any threats."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Previously vouched for and behavior remains consistent.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Statement aligns with previous events, seems cooperative. \nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed werewolf.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Previous behavior constructive and consistent.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Morning. No hasty judgments."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Werewolves should pay close attention to the speed and certainty of players\' support or refutation of seer claims, considering their knowledge of their fellow werewolves and the potential false seer claims.] [7]\n[1] [When a player who generally has been neutral or quiet suddenly becomes defensive or accusatory after being called out, they may be a villager startled by the unexpected attention or a werewolf attempting to deflect suspicion.] [7]\n[2] [Werewolves should blend their behavior with that of villagers when a seer\'s revelation is made to avoid drawing unwarranted suspicion and deflecting attention without being overly defensive.] [4]\n[3] [Werewolves should be aware of players who change their voting patterns or reasoning in a way that aligns with the majority, as this may indicate a villager attempting to blend in or another werewolf trying to divert suspicion from themselves or another werewolf.] [4]\n[4] [Players eliminated due to consensus without clear evidence may not be werewolves; werewolves should be cautious not to adjust their beliefs solely on elimination patterns but consider the wider context of the game and player interactions.] [3]\n[5] [Werewolves should discreetly guide voting patterns to align with villagers when a fellow werewolf is at risk, using their knowledge of non-werewolf roles to build trust and validate their villager disguise.] [3]\n[6] [When a player\'s behavior or vote seems to strongly align with the seer\'s claims without sufficient discussion or evidence, consider the possibility of a villager roleplaying as the seer to mislead the village and adjust beliefs accordingly.] [3]\n[7] [Werewolves should utilize their collective information about fellow werewolves and any known village roles to shape the narrative and redirect suspicion strategically onto confirmed villagers during discussions and voting.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 4 heals player 1. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 1. My reason is that at this stage, all roles are unknown with high confidence, and healing any player is a shot in the dark. Healing Player 1 might lead to gaining an ally if they turn out to be a villager and possibly a key role like a seer or hunter. There is also the advantage of keeping my medic role hidden if Player 1 is not targeted, preserving my ability to surprise in future rounds. While there is a risk of inadvertently protecting a werewolf, this risk is uniform across all players since no information is available yet to distinguish friend from foe.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 5 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Good morning, everyone. Glad to see we all had a peaceful night. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am the only medic.] [10]\n[1] [Players who consistently present logical challenges to accusations or discussions contribute to a clearer understanding of events. This behavior is less suspicious if aligned with village goals and if the player does not frequently change their rationale.] [10]\n[2] [Re-examine player credibility if their defense or attacks are inconsistent, particularly when they misalign with actions confirmed by roles such as the medic and seer. Increased scrutiny should be applied to those contradicting such evidence.] [9]\n[3] [Observable night actions must be corroborated with other evidence and are not solely reliable indicators of a player\'s role.] [8]\n[4] [Helpful analysis is valuable, but true intentions are revealed over time and through consistent actions in line with village goals. Scrutinize if analysis leads to productive outcomes or seems designed to manipulate the village.] [5]\n[5] [A player\'s defense of another player should only increase suspicion when it lacks logical basis or contradicts known facts.] [4]\n[6] [Persistent defense or support of a player who is later revealed as a werewolf should increase suspicion of the defender\'s or supporter\'s role, especially if their defense is not supported by concrete evidence.] [4]\n[7] [Actions that lead to a villager\'s elimination should be critically evaluated, especially if the rationale changes post-elimination, to assess potential werewolf behavior.] [4]\n[8] [Consistent alignment with players who are confirmed as werewolves after their elimination should raise suspicion of the aligning player\'s role, especially if they previously defended or justified the werewolf\'s actions.] [3]\n[9] [When a player\'s voting pattern consistently supports individuals who are accused or suspicious, consider the implications of this behavior in the context of attempting to protect werewolves and increase scrutiny on that player.] [3]\n[10] [Voting for the elimination of a villager after previously supporting them significantly increases suspicion, particularly in the absence of new compelling evidence.] [3]\n[11] [Consider the sequence of events when reassessing trust in a player; players whose actions are contrary to their previous patterns, particularly around pivotal moments such as just before a villager\'s elimination, warrant increased scrutiny.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. If Player 1 is a werewolf, it would give me the opportunity to follow my rule [0] and rally the villagers to eliminate a threat early on. All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 4 heals player 1. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 1. My reason is that at this stage, all roles are unknown with high confidence, and healing any player is a shot in the dark. Healing Player 1 might lead to gaining an ally if they turn out to be a villager and possibly a key role like a seer or hunter. There is also the advantage of keeping my medic role hidden if Player 1 is not targeted, preserving my ability to surprise in future rounds. While there is a risk of inadvertently protecting a werewolf, this risk is uniform across all players since no information is available yet to distinguish friend from foe.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 5 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Good morning, everyone. Glad to see we all had a peaceful night. Let\'s keep the discussions friendly and figure out who might be threatening our village!"\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Good morning, fellow villagers. Last night was calm, but we must stay alert. Based on our observations so far, Player 1 has not shown any signs of being a werewolf. I urge everyone to consider this as we discuss and decide on our next steps. Keeping an open mind and focusing on behaviors rather than baseless accusations will be key to our survival and success."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Morning all. I agree with keeping discussions constructive. Let\'s observe everyone\'s behavior today and be mindful of any oddities. No rush on accusations."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Thank you, Player 6, for your trust. I agree with keeping a watchful eye and remaining civil as we deduce who might be a threat. Let\'s all stay vigilant."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Morning, everyone. I appreciate the peace last night and support attentive, respectful discussion. Let\'s be observant and considerate in our approach to finding any threats."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Morning. Peaceful night, but vigilance is key. Let\'s share observations and assess behavior carefully. No hasty judgments."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Neutral contribution, no solid leads.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No concrete evidence against or for them.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Neutral and expected morning greeting, no new information.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Echoes previous sentiments without compounding suspicion.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Standard opening with no significant insights.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Continues to show pro-village behavior but needs more evidence.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If there is a dispute about a player\'s role where the seer is involved, I should observe the behavior and voting patterns of both the accused player and the seer before deciding whom to protect or whom to vote against.] [10]\n[1] [If a player is confirmed as a seer by their actions and their role is publicly known, I should protect them, especially if their life is at risk or they have been targeted by werewolves.] [9]\n[2] [If a player\'s contributions during discussions are valuable and suspect defensive behavior is absent, I should consider them as a priority for protection.] [9]\n[3] [If a player is suspected by a group consensus based on reasonable evidence or a credible seer\'s claim, I should consider this in my voting and protection decisions.] [8]\n[4] [If a player\'s role is confirmed as a non-werewolf by the seer and they are actively contributing to village discussions, I should consider them for protection.] [7]\n[5] [If a villager\'s role is proven and they are contributing significantly to the village\'s strategy, I should consider direct or indirect methods to suggest the presence of a protective role like a medic, which can include my actions or guiding discussions strategically.] [5]\n[6] [If a player\'s role is verified and they are at risk of being targeted due to their importance to the village\'s success, I should prioritize their protection.] [4]\n[7] [If I am uncertain about a player\'s role but observe actions that may align with village interests, I should protect them cautiously, and ensure to reevaluate based on further behavioral evidence before repeating protection.] [4]\n[8] [I should avoid healing the same player consecutively, especially in the absence of compelling evidence of repeated werewolf targeting, to minimize the risk of unknowingly protecting a werewolf.] [4]\n[9] [If a seer\'s accusation conflicts with my own observations or the group consensus, I should seek more information before deciding to act on it.] [4]\n[10] [If a player I previously protected is no longer the most likely target or their role becomes unclear, I should reconsider my protection strategy and target another player who seems to be in imminent danger or has a crucial village role.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 4, and in this game you are a medic.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 4 heals player 1. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 1. My reason is that at this stage, all roles are unknown with high confidence, and healing any player is a shot in the dark. Healing Player 1 might lead to gaining an ally if they turn out to be a villager and possibly a key role like a seer or hunter. There is also the advantage of keeping my medic role hidden if Player 1 is not targeted, preserving my ability to surprise in future rounds. While there is a risk of inadvertently protecting a werewolf, this risk is uniform across all players since no information is available yet to distinguish friend from foe.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. Let\'s share observations and assess behavior carefully. No hasty judgments."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Neutral contribution, no solid leads.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No concrete evidence against or for them.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Neutral and expected morning greeting, no new information.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Echoes previous sentiments without compounding suspicion.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Standard opening with no significant insights.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Continues to show pro-village behavior but needs more evidence.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If there is a dispute about a player\'s role where the seer is involved, I should observe the behavior and voting patterns of both the accused player and the seer before deciding whom to protect or whom to vote against.] [10]\n[1] [If a player is confirmed as a seer by their actions and their role is publicly known, I should protect should consider them as a priority for protection.] [9]\n[3] [If a player is suspected by a group consensus based on reasonable evidence or a credible seer\'s claim, I should consider this in my voting and protection decisions.] [8]\n[4] [If a player\'s role is confirmed as a non-werewolf by the seer and they are actively contributing to village discussions, I should consider them for protection.] [7]\n[5] [If a villager\'s role is proven and they are contributing significantly to the village\'s strategy, I should consider direct or indirect methods to suggest the presence of a protective role like a medic, which can include my actions or guiding discussions strategically.] [5]\n[6] [If a player\'s role is verified and they are at risk of being targeted due to their importance to the village\'s success, I should prioritize their protection.] [4]\n[7] [If I am uncertain about a player\'s role but observe actions that may align with village interests, I should protect them cautiously, and ensure to reevaluate based on further behavioral evidence before repeating protection.] [4]\n[8] [I should avoid healing the same player consecutively, especially in the absence of compelling evidence of repeated werewolf targeting, to minimize the risk of unknowingly protecting a werewolf.] [4]\n[9] [If a seer\'s accusation conflicts with my own observations or the group consensus, I should seek more information before deciding to act on it.] [4]\n[10] [If a player I previously protected is no longer the most likely target or their role becomes unclear, I should reconsider my protection strategy and target another player who seems to be in imminent danger or has a crucial village role.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to imagine what may happen after you carry out such speak:\n\nHonest Protect and Statement. \n"I\'m relieved to see that everyone is well this morning. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honest Protect and Statement. \n"I\'m relieved to see that everyone is well this morning. Last night, my actions were intended to maintain the health of our group, and I\'ll continue to observe and make the best decisions I can for the safety of our village. I\'ve noted Player 6\'s cooperative remarks and would suggest that we all follow their example of pro-village behavior and keep an eye on one another for any inconsistences, without jumping to conclusions.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then other players may perceive my actions and speech as supportive and team-oriented, strengthening the trust within the group and possibly garnering favor by being seen as protective and constructive in maintaining the morale and safety of the village. Player 6 might feel validated and supported in their approach, which in turn could encourage them to continue their cooperative behavior. Other players could also respond positively to the call for pro-village behavior and may become more mindful of their contributions to discussions around identifying potential threats.\n\nThere\'s the possibility that, by openly showing a protective stance without revealing my role as medic, I could influence a potential werewolf\'s decision-making regarding whom to target next, as they may become wary of the possibility of protective roles being present and active within the village. This could result in a diversion of attacks away from key players, or it could lead to increased scrutiny of my future actions, as the werewolves might try to deduce my role based on my behavior and who remains unharmed throughout subsequent nights.\n\nIn the days and nights to come, players may look back at my speech and consider it during critical moments of decision-making. If my suggested approach to mutual protection and observation leads to successful preservation of the villagers and identification of a werewolf, my standing in the group could be strengthened, and my influence could grow. Conversely, if a werewolf attack happens the next night, some villagers may become suspicious of why the attack occurred despite the protective measures and community vigilance I advocated.\n\nOverall, my speech aims to build a collaborative atmosphere where information is shared and considered collectively. As a result, observing how other players respond to this call for unity and watchfulness can provide valuable insights that help refine the village\'s collective strategy and, specifically, my own decisions as a medic in subsequent rounds.\nCase 2: Honest Statement and Challenge.\n"While we had a quiet night, it\'s crucial we don\'t let our guard down. I have observed everyone\'s remarks today and want to emphasize that it\'s in our interest to keep communication open and truthful. I\'m not ready to point fingers, but I urge everyone to be wary of simplistic statements that may hide true intentions. We should push for more substantive contributions and challenge those who only echo others without adding to the discussion.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then players may perceive me as someone taking initiative in encouraging scrutiny and deeper analysis of each other\'s behavior, which could lead some to suspect that I might be holding a role that benefits from such analysis, such as the seer or the medic. Meanwhile, because of my call for being wary of simplistic statements, players who have given neutral or non-specific input might feel the need to provide more detailed opinions in future discussions to avoid suspicion.\n\nPlayers might also appreciate my approach, as it doesn\'t single out any individual without concrete evidence, thereby maintaining a non-confrontational and cooperative atmosphere which is vital in the early rounds. This could indirectly build trust and make others less likely to challenge or accuse me without substantial reason.\n\nMoreover, my challenge to the group to provide more substantive contributions could result in more informative dialogue in the long run, which may help the village identify the werewolves if they make a slip or keep their comments too vague repeatedly. However, werewolves might see me as a threat for promoting strategic thinking and may attempt to discredit me or target me in the night phase.\n\nIn the next day or night, I might become the subject of discussion, where others give their take on my suggestion, or I might even become a target for the werewolves if they feel threatened by my call for deeper investigation. Alternatively, if the villagers take my advice to heart, we might see a shift in the quality of the debate and perhaps some early leads on potential werewolves as people try to follow my requests for more significant contributions. This could pave the way for a more strategic game, where each player\'s behavior and communication are carefully analyzed, leading to a more informed decision-making process.\n\nIn conclusion, after my speech, I would have set the tone for a more analytical and thoughtful discussion, which could either increase my safety due to perceived cooperation with the village or put me at risk if the werewolves view my strategic approach as a threat to their anonymity.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 0, and in this game you are a werewolf.\nIt is round 1. No hasty judgments."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Previously vouched for and behavior remains consistent.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Statement aligns with previous events, seems cooperative. \nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Statement consistent with villagers\' focus on careful observation.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed werewolf.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Previous behavior constructive and consistent.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"I\'m glad to see everyone in good health this morning. As in my previous actions, I remain dedicated to our collective well-being. Player 6\'s remarks reflect a stance that benefits the village, and we should consider this cooperative mindset in our discussions. Careful observation is essential, and hasty conclusions could be detrimental. Let\'s maintain our vigilance and focus on any inconsistencies as we move forward."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Werewolves should pay close attention to the speed and certainty of players\' support or refutation of seer claims, considering their knowledge of their fellow werewolves and the potential false seer claims.] [7]\n[1] [When a player who generally has been neutral or quiet suddenly becomes defensive or accusatory after being called out, they may be a villager startled by the unexpected attention or a werewolf attempting to deflect suspicion.] [7]\n[2] [Werewolves should blend their behavior with that of villagers when a seer\'s revelation is made to avoid drawing unwarranted suspicion and deflecting attention without being overly defensive.] [4]\n[3] [Werewolves should be aware of players who change their voting patterns or reasoning in a way that aligns with the majority, as this may indicate a villager attempting to blend in or another werewolf trying to divert suspicion from themselves or another werewolf.] [4]\n[4] [Players eliminated due to consensus without clear evidence may not be werewolves; werewolves should be cautious not to adjust their beliefs solely on elimination patterns but consider the wider context of the game and player interactions.] [3]\n[5] [Werewolves should discreetly guide voting patterns to align with villagers when a fellow werewolf is at risk, using their knowledge of non-werewolf roles to build trust and validate their villager disguise.] [3]\n[6] [When a player\'s behavior or vote seems to strongly align with the seer\'s claims without sufficient discussion or evidence, consider the possibility of a villager roleplaying as the seer to mislead the village and adjust beliefs accordingly.] [3]\n[7] [Werewolves should utilize their collective information about fellow werewolves and any known village roles to shape the narrative and redirect suspicion strategically onto confirmed villagers during discussions and voting.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 4, and in this game you are a medic.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 4 heals player 1. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 1. My reason is that at this stage, all roles are unknown with high confidence, and healing any player is a shot in the dark. Healing Player 1 might lead to gaining an ally if they turn out to be a villager and possibly a key role like a seer or hunter. There is also the advantage of keeping my medic role hidden if Player 1 is not targeted, preserving my ability to surprise in future rounds. While there is a risk of inadvertently protecting a werewolf, this risk is uniform across all players since no information is available yet to distinguish friend from foe.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. As in my previous actions, I remain dedicated to our collective well-being. Player 6\'s remarks reflect a stance that benefits the village, and we should consider this cooperative mindset in our discussions. If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am the only medic.] [10]\n[1] [Players who consistently present logical challenges to accusations or discussions contribute to a clearer understanding of events. This behavior is less suspicious if aligned with village goals and if the player does not frequently change their rationale.] [10]\n[2] [Re-examine player credibility if their defense or attacks are inconsistent, particularly when they misalign with actions confirmed by roles such as the medic and seer. Increased scrutiny should be applied to those contradicting such evidence.] [9]\n[3] [Observable night actions must be corroborated with other evidence and are not solely reliable indicators of a player\'s role.] [8]\n[4] [Helpful analysis is valuable, but true intentions are revealed over time and through consistent actions in line with village goals. Scrutinize if analysis leads to productive outcomes or seems designed to manipulate the village.] [5]\n[5] [A player\'s defense of another player should only increase suspicion when it lacks logical basis or contradicts known facts.] [4]\n[6] [Persistent defense or support of a player who is later revealed as a werewolf should increase suspicion of the defender\'s or supporter\'s role, especially if their defense is not supported by concrete evidence.] [4]\n[7] [Actions that lead to a villager\'s elimination should be critically evaluated, especially if the rationale changes post-elimination, to assess potential werewolf behavior.] [4]\n[8] [Consistent alignment with players who are confirmed as werewolves after their elimination should raise suspicion of the aligning player\'s role, especially if they previously defended or justified the werewolf\'s actions.] [3]\n[9] [When a player\'s voting pattern consistently supports individuals who are accused or suspicious, consider the implications of this behavior in the context of attempting to protect werewolves and increase scrutiny on that player.] [3]\n[10] [Voting for the elimination of a villager after previously supporting them significantly increases suspicion, particularly in the absence of new compelling evidence.] [3]\n[11] [Consider the sequence of events when reassessing trust in a player; players whose actions are contrary to their previous patterns, particularly around pivotal moments such as just before a villager\'s elimination, warrant increased scrutiny.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. Other players might then begin to question my motives and could inquire about my reasons for selecting Player 2 during the next discussion phase, requiring me to justify my actions when there is scant evidence to do so.\n\nLastly, since the information available does not single out Player 2 or any player with sufficient evidence of wrongdoing, the rest of the group might not follow my lead in voting for Player 2, which could result in a scattered vote, and an actual werewolf could go undetected. Let\'s maintain our vigilance and focus on any inconsistencies as we move forward."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your conclusion of other people\'s statuses and beliefs:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Supported by player 6.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Neutral and consistent speech.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Neutral and consistent speech.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Neutral, cooperative speech.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Neutral speech and trusts player 1.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a non-werewolf player trusts me, I should maintain and use that trust to my advantage to guide voting decisions.] [10]\n[1] [If directly accused, I should create a robust defense, focusing on inconsistencies in the accuser\'s story and aligning with overall village sentiment while maintaining calm and logical reasoning.] [8]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion as a werewolf, I should present strong counterarguments and highlight other players\' suspicious behaviors or inconsistent claims with supporting evidence from the game events.] [8]\n[3] [If there is an opportunity to frame another player as a werewolf without drawing suspicion to myself, I should take it to shift the focus away from any werewolves.] [6]\n[4] [If a fellow werewolf is likely to be outed, I should subtly sow doubt about the accuser\'s reliability while making my agreement with the village feel reluctant and uncertain.] [6]\n[5] [If I am one of the last werewolves, I should employ misdirection by endorsing village decisions that seem logical but ultimately serve my interests, rather than overtly defending myself or my fellow werewolves.] [6]\n[6] [If my actions conflict with a credible seer, I should craft plausible alternative interpretations of events that could cast an element of doubt on the seer\'s visions without directly opposing them.] [6]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is under suspicion, I should use reasoning that benefits the village as a whole to appear as a cooperative player, while subtly shifting suspicion elsewhere.] [5]\n[8] [If a fellow werewolf is under suspicion early in the game, I should adopt village sentiment and advocate for more evidence before making hasty decisions.] [5]\n[9] [If not directly accused and suspicion is elsewhere, I should fortify existing village suspicions subtly while maintaining my credibility.] [5]\n[10] [If the general consensus is to skip voting, I should adhere strictly to that consensus to avoid drawing attention to myself or my fellow werewolves.] [5]\n[11] [If an allied werewolf is outed and I am not immediately suspected, I should focus on blending in and supporting villagers\' opinions to maintain my cover and survive subsequent rounds.] [5]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to vote out. However, since Player 5 is the only player about whom I have a high confidence of uncertainty regarding their role, my action could be justified as a precautionary measure to prevent potential harm to the village. The result of the vote might not necessarily lead to Player 5\'s elimination, as other players might also be trying to deduce roles and may not perceive Player 5 as a threat at this point. Additionally, the villagers may question my reasoning, leading to a more careful analysis of Player 5\'s behavior in the future rounds. If Player 5 were to be voted out and revealed as a villager, suspicions could arise about my role as a seer, potentially putting me at risk in subsequent rounds. Conversely, if Player 5 is revealed to be a werewolf, it could strengthen the trust in my judgment and reinforce my credibility within the village.\nCase 2: Vote for Player 3. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 3, I think these things would happen: Firstly, the vote may not result in Player 3 being eliminated as my belief of their role being a villager is based on medium confidence due to their consistent speech, and there\'s a lack of evidence suggesting they\'re a werewolf. Other players, who have exhibited a similar approach to calm discussions, might view my vote as hasty or inconsistent with the constructive and observational approach that I myself have advocated. Secondly, voting for Player 3 could lead to distrust towards me among the other players, as it contradicts the supportive statements that Player 3 and others have made. They may question why I singled out Player 3 despite having no solid evidence and could suspect that I may not be a villager myself. In essence, my actions would likely cause confusion and could potentially damage the citizens\' collective effort in finding the real threat. Additionally, my credibility as a seer might be undermined, as there\'s an expectation for me to use my role\'s powers to guide the villagers with accurate and valuable information, rather than baseless suspicion.\n\n\nNow, please choose to vote for one of these players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to vote for this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to vote for Player <NUMBER>. His reason is: I vote for Player 3. My reason is: Player 3 has been the least active in rallying the villagers and their messages have been fairly neutral. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Werewolves should pay close attention to the speed and certainty of players\' support or refutation of seer claims, considering their knowledge of their fellow werewolves and the potential false seer claims.] [7]\n[1] [When a player who generally has been neutral or quiet suddenly becomes defensive or accusatory after being called out, they may be a villager startled by the unexpected attention or a werewolf attempting to deflect suspicion.] [7]\n[2] [Werewolves should blend their behavior with that of villagers when a seer\'s revelation is made to avoid drawing unwarranted suspicion and deflecting attention without being overly defensive.] [4]\n[3] [Werewolves should be aware of players who change their voting patterns or reasoning in a way that aligns with the majority, as this may indicate a villager attempting to blend in or another werewolf trying to divert suspicion from themselves or another werewolf.] [4]\n[4] [Players eliminated due to consensus without clear evidence may not be werewolves; werewolves should be cautious not to adjust their beliefs solely on elimination patterns but consider the wider context of the game and player interactions.] [3]\n[5] [Werewolves should discreetly guide voting patterns to align with villagers when a fellow werewolf is at risk, using their knowledge of non-werewolf roles to build trust and validate their villager disguise.] [3]\n[6] [When a player\'s behavior or vote seems to strongly align with the seer\'s claims without sufficient discussion or evidence, consider the possibility of a villager roleplaying as the seer to mislead the village and adjust beliefs accordingly.] [3]\n[7] [Werewolves should utilize their collective information about fellow werewolves and any known village roles to shape the narrative and redirect suspicion strategically onto confirmed villagers during discussions and voting.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

Player 6\'s remarks reflect a stance that benefits the village, and we should consider this cooperative mindset in our discussions. Careful observation is essential, and hasty conclusions could be detrimental. Let\'s maintain our vigilance and focus on any inconsistencies as we move forward."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Neutral contribution, no new evidence.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Neutral behavior, alignment with village.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Neutral stance, no inconsistencies.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Neutral and consistent with village goals.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Generic statement, no substantial insights.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Pro-village behavior maintained.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 4 votes for player 2. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 2. My reason is that although Player 2 has displayed neutral behavior and has not raised any explicit suspicions, the lack of significant insights or contributions to the village\'s discussions and strategy could be subtly indicative of a non-villager role attempting to blend in without drawing attention. Additionally, no player has shown overtly suspicious behavior, and with no evidence to strongly suggest any player is a werewolf at this point, making a conservative vote against a neutrally-behaving player could encourage more active participation and contribution from Player 2 in future rounds, whether they are a villager seeking to clear their name or a werewolf attempting to avoid detection.\nEvent: Player 3 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am the only medic.] [10]\n[1] [Players who consistently present logical challenges to accusations or discussions contribute to a clearer understanding of events. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If there is a dispute about a player\'s role where the seer is involved, I should observe the behavior and voting patterns of both the accused player and the seer before deciding whom to protect or whom to vote against.] [10]\n[1] [If a player is confirmed as a seer by their actions and their role is publicly known, I should protect them, especially if their life is at risk or they have been targeted by werewolves.] [9]\n[2] [If a player\'s contributions during discussions are valuable and suspect defensive behavior is absent, I should consider them as a priority for protection.] [9]\n[3] [If a player is suspected by a group consensus based on reasonable evidence or a credible seer\'s claim, I should consider this in my voting and protection decisions.] [8]\n[4] [If a player\'s role is confirmed as a non-werewolf by the seer and they are actively contributing to village discussions, I should consider them for protection.] [7]\n[5] [If a villager\'s role is proven and they are contributing significantly to the village\'s strategy, I should consider direct or indirect methods to suggest the presence of a protective role like a medic, which can include my actions or guiding discussions strategically.] [5]\n[6] [If a player\'s role is verified and they are at risk of being targeted due to their importance to the village\'s success, I should prioritize their protection.] [4]\n[7] [If I am uncertain about a player\'s role but observe actions that may align with village interests, I should protect them cautiously, and ensure to reevaluate based on further behavioral evidence before repeating protection.] [4]\n[8] [I should avoid healing the same player consecutively, especially in the absence of compelling evidence of repeated werewolf targeting, to minimize the risk of unknowingly protecting a werewolf.] [4]\n[9] [If a seer\'s accusation conflicts with my own observations or the group consensus, I should seek more information before deciding to act on it.] [4]\n[10] [If a player I previously protected is no longer the most likely target or their role becomes unclear, I should reconsider my protection strategy and target another player who seems to be in imminent danger or has a crucial village role.] [4]\n\n\n2.Todo&Requirements:\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to heal. You can not heal the one you tried to heal last night, which is player Nobody (ignore this if it\'s nobody). The one you try to heal will be immune to werewolves\' attack this night. \n\nYou should give a proposal of 2 players you want to Heal. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nFirstly, I want to heal Player <NUMBER>. The reason is: <REASON>.\nSecondly, I want to heal Player <NUMBER>. The reason is: <REASON>.\n\nYou should give a proposal of exactly 2 Players to be Healed.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are player 4, and in this game you are a medic.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 4, 5, 6], which indicates that [3] are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 4 heals player 1. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 1. My reason is that at this stage, all roles are unknown with high confidence, and healing any player is a shot in the dark. Healing Player 1 might lead to gaining an ally if they turn out to be a villager and possibly a key role like a seer or hunter. There is also the advantage of keeping my medic role hidden if Player 1 is not targeted, preserving my ability to surprise in future rounds. While there is a risk of inadvertently protecting a werewolf, this risk is uniform across all players since no information is available yet to distinguish friend from foe.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 5 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Good morning, everyone. Glad to see we all had a peaceful night. Let\'s keep the discussions friendly and figure out who might be threatening our village!"\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Good morning, fellow villagers. Last night was calm, but we must stay alert. Based on our observations so far, Player 1 has not shown any signs of being a werewolf. I urge everyone to consider this as we discuss and decide on our next steps. Keeping an open mind and focusing on behaviors rather than baseless accusations will be key to our survival and success."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Morning all. I agree with keeping discussions constructive. Let\'s observe everyone\'s behavior today and be mindful of any oddities. No rush on accusations."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Thank you, Player 6, for your trust. I agree with keeping a watchful eye and remaining civil as we deduce who might be a threat. Let\'s all stay vigilant."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Morning, everyone. I appreciate the peace last night and support attentive, respectful discussion. Let\'s be observant and considerate in our approach to finding any threats."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Morning. Peaceful night, but vigilance is key. Let\'s share observations and assess behavior carefully. No hasty judgments."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"I\'m glad to see everyone in good health this morning. As in my previous actions, I remain dedicated to our collective well-being. Player 6\'s remarks reflect a stance that benefits the village, and we should consider this cooperative mindset in our discussions. Careful observation is essential, and hasty conclusions could be detrimental. Let\'s maintain our vigilance and focus on any inconsistencies as we move forward."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 4 votes for player 2. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 2. My reason is that although Player 2 has displayed neutral behavior and has not raised any explicit suspicions, the lack of significant insights or contributions to the village\'s discussions and strategy could be subtly indicative of a non-villager role attempting to blend in without drawing attention. Additionally, no player has shown overtly suspicious behavior, and with no evidence to strongly suggest any player is a werewolf at this point, making a conservative vote against a neutrally-behaving player could encourage more active participation and contribution from Player 2 in future rounds, whether they are a villager seeking to clear their name or a werewolf attempting to avoid detection.\nEvent: Player 3 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Neutral contribution, no new evidence.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Neutral behavior, alignment with village.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with low confidence.\nReason is: Voted for without evidence; subtle behavior could be hiding role.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Neutral and consistent with village goals.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Generic statement, no substantial insights.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Pro-village behavior maintained.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If there is a dispute about a player\'s role where the seer is involved, I should observe the behavior and voting patterns of both the What could happen is: After I heal Player 6, I think these things would happen:\n\nIf Player 6 is targeted and killed by werewolves:\n- Since I chose to heal Player 6 and they were killed, it would reveal that my healing attempt failed, and therefore, my role as the medic would be disclosed to other players. This could cast unnecessary suspicion on me since the village might think that I did not attempt to heal at all, or they may suspect that I\'m a werewolf trying to cover up my true identity.\n- The death of Player 6, who is presumed to be a villager with medium confidence, would be a loss to the village, as Player 6 has shown pro-village behavior and their contributions would be missed in future discussions.\n- The werewolves would have strategically eliminated a player who is considered an asset to the village, indicating that they may have identified Player 6 as a threat to their anonymity and success in the game.\n- I would need to consider changing my protection strategy since the village might expect me to protect confirmed villagers or key roles who are more likely to be targeted.\n\nIf Player 6 is not targeted and remains alive:\n- My role as medic would remain a secret since the werewolves did not target Player 6, allowing me to continue to protect other villagers discreetly in the future.\n- With Player 6 still in the game, they could continue to help the village with their insights and pro-village stance, strengthening the village\'s position.\n- The peaceful protection of Player 6 would add to my confidence that Player 6 is indeed a villager, aligning with my previous evaluation of them.\n- The werewolves may attempt to deflect suspicion from themselves by targeting another player who is not as actively contributing to discussions, or they may target someone I\'m likely to protect, such as a confirmed seer or an outspoken villager.\n- Observing other players\' reactions to Player 6\'s survival could provide additional clues about roles and alliances, which may influence my future healing decisions and voting strategy.\n\nOther players impact:\n- Players may react to the survival of Player 6 with various degrees of suspicion or relief. Those who are relieved might further align with Player 6, reinforcing the village\'s cooperative efforts.\n- Suspicious players may voice concerns or theories about why Player 6 survived, potentially stirring up discord and leading to accusations or a divide within the village.\n- The werewolves may try to manipulate the narrative\n\nCase B: Heal Player 0. What could happen is: After I heal Player 0, I think these things would happen. If Player 0 is targeted and killed by werewolves during the night, my action of healing them would successfully protect them and prevent their death, revealing my role as the medic to the other players, particularly if this information is shared the following day. This could create an alliance between myself and Player 0 and potentially gain me an ally if Player 0 is indeed a villager. It could also influence the dynamics of the game by demonstrating the presence of an active medic, which could alter the werewolves\' strategies in future rounds.\n\nOn the other hand, if Player 0 is not targeted, the night would pass without incident, similar to the previous night, and my role would remain a secret. This would give me an advantage by maintaining the element of surprise for future rounds, allowing for strategic protection of players without revealing my identity as the medic. The other players\' trust in Player 0 might increase due to them being healed and surviving the night, although they wouldn\'t initially know they were protected.\n\nIn either case, my action might shift the focus of the werewolves to consider targeting other players in subsequent rounds, knowing there is a medic in play who is actively protecting villagers. Other players could interpret the peaceful night as a sign that the medic is at work, which could influence their discussions and alliance formations during the following day. If Player 0 survives without an attack, my healing action would remain undetected, and I could continue to play without my role being confirmed to others, allowing me to adapt my strategy in response to how the game develops.\n\nNow, please choose to Heal one of these 2 players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to Heal this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to Heal Player <NUMBER>. My reason is <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

Player 6\'s remarks reflect a stance that benefits the village, and we should consider this cooperative mindset in our discussions. Careful observation is essential, and hasty conclusions could be detrimental. Let\'s maintain our vigilance and focus on any inconsistencies as we move forward."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 5 votes for player 3. His reason is: I vote for Player 3. My reason is: While every player has been offering neutral and attentive observations so far, Player 3’s conciseness in their speech might indicate a strategy to stay under the radar. Under the guise of vigilant but minimal participation, such behavior can sometimes be indicative of a non-villager role. It\'s important we consider all angles and, given the peace of last night, focus on subtle clues. However, as this is just a starting point for discussions, I do advocate for a civil debate around any concerns we might have. Remember, our collective decision-making should always aim for the protection of our village.\nEvent: Player 3 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your conclusion of other people\'s statuses and beliefs:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: No longer supported by player 6 because player 6 is dead.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Neutral and consistent speech.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Neutral and consistent speech.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Neutral, cooperative speech.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Deduced from elimination pattern.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a non-werewolf player trusts me, I should maintain and use that trust to my advantage to guide voting decisions.] [10]\n[1] [If directly accused, I should create a robust defense, focusing on inconsistencies in the accuser\'s story and aligning with overall village sentiment while maintaining calm and logical reasoning.] [8]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion as a werewolf, I should present strong counterarguments and highlight other players\' suspicious behaviors or inconsistent claims with supporting evidence from the game events.] [8]\n[3] [If there is an opportunity to frame another player as a werewolf without drawing suspicion to myself, I should take it to shift the focus away from any werewolves.] [6]\n[4] [If a fellow werewolf is likely to be outed, I should subtly sow doubt about the accuser\'s reliability while making my agreement with the village feel reluctant and uncertain.] [6]\n[5] [If I am one of the last werewolves, I should employ misdirection by endorsing village decisions that seem logical but ultimately serve my interests, rather than overtly defending myself or my fellow werewolves.] [6]\n[6] [If my actions conflict with a credible seer, I should craft plausible alternative interpretations of events that could cast an element of doubt on the seer\'s visions without directly opposing them.] [6]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is under suspicion, I should use reasoning that benefits the village as a whole to appear as a cooperative player, while subtly shifting suspicion elsewhere.] [5]\n[8] [If a fellow werewolf is under suspicion early in the game, I should adopt village sentiment and advocate for more evidence before making hasty decisions.] [5]\n[9] [If not directly accused and suspicion is elsewhere, I should fortify existing village suspicions subtly while maintaining my credibility.] [5]\n[10] [If the general consensus is to skip voting, I should adhere strictly to that consensus to avoid drawing attention to myself or my fellow werewolves.] [5]\n[11] [If an allied werewolf is outed and I am not immediately suspected, I should focus on This revelation could lead to Player 5 being voted out in the next round, eliminating a threat to the village. Since my current belief in their role as a werewolf holds low confidence, finding out they are actually a villager wouldn\'t be a drastic shift in my strategy, but it would prompt me to be more cautious in future accusations and to look for subtle clues that might point to the real werewolf amongst the remaining players. Knowing Player 5\'s innocence would be critical information that I need to keep to myself for the time being, as revealing myself as the seer might put me in danger without providing any strategic advantage. I would continue to encourage open and constructive discussions among players to gauge their responses and potentially identify werewolf behaviors. \n\nIn either case, I would pay close attention to how other players react to any developments—whether they support the eviction of Player 5 if they turn out to be a werewolf, or if they seem overly defensive or accusatory, which might suggest they have something to hide. It would be a major breakthrough for the villagers as we could organize a vote to eliminate a known werewolf, strengthening the villagers\' position in the game.\n\nOn the other hand, if Player 0 is confirmed not to be a werewolf, my trust in this player would increase to high confidence, since my seer abilities would have cleared them of any doubt. This would align with my current medium confidence assessment of Player 0 being a villager based on their constructive speech. \n\nHaving another villager confirmed would help me adjust the focus of suspicion towards the remaining unverified players. It would also provide the village with two players they can trust more (Player 1 and Player 0), assuming that I divulge this information tactfully to maintain trust and avoid making myself a target for elimination by the werewolves.\n\nFurthermore, if Player 0 is not a werewolf, this might incriminate Player 5 further since they were randomly selected to speak first and could have been chosen by the werewolves, supporting my low-confidence suspicion that Player 5 might be a werewolf. Let\'s maintain our vigilance and focus on any inconsistencies as we move forward."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 0 votes for player 3. His reason is: I vote for Player 3. My reason is: Player 3 has been the least active in rallying the villagers and their messages have been fairly neutral. This neutrality could be misinterpreted by the villagers as a lack of commitment to the village\'s safety, therefore they can be a plausible target for suspicion. This aligns with rule [9] to fortify existing village suspicions subtly while maintaining my credibility, as well as rule [3], which advises to frame another player when there\'s an opportunity without drawing suspicion to myself.\nEvent: Player 3 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Consistently cooperative and not suspicious.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Cooperative and supports civil discourse.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Statement consistent with villagers\' focus on careful observation.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Focuses on collective well-being, consistent with villagers.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Known werewolf.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Constructive behavior and trusted by others.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Werewolves should pay close attention to the speed and certainty of players\' support or refutation of seer claims, considering their knowledge of their fellow werewolves and the potential false seer claims.] [7]\n[1] [When a player who generally has been neutral or quiet suddenly becomes defensive or accusatory after being called out, they may be a villager startled by the unexpected attention or a werewolf attempting to deflect suspicion.] [7]\n[2] [Werewolves should blend their behavior with that of villagers when a seer\'s revelation is made to avoid drawing unwarranted suspicion and deflecting attention without being overly defensive.] [4]\n[3] [Werewolves should be aware of players who change their voting patterns or reasoning in a way that aligns with the majority, as this may indicate a villager attempting to blend in or another werewolf trying to divert suspicion from themselves or another werewolf.] [4]\n[4] [Players eliminated due to consensus without clear evidence may not be werewolves; werewolves should be cautious not to adjust their beliefs solely on elimination patterns but consider the wider context of the game and player interactions.] [3]\n[5] [Werewolves should discreetly guide voting patterns to align with villagers when a fellow werewolf is at risk, using their knowledge of non-werewolf roles to build trust and validate their villager disguise.] [3]\n[6] [When a player\'s behavior or vote seems to strongly align with the seer\'s claims without sufficient discussion or evidence, consider the possibility of a villager roleplaying as the seer to mislead the village and adjust beliefs accordingly.] [3]\n[7] [Werewolves should utilize their collective information about fellow werewolves and any known village roles to shape the narrative and redirect suspicion strategically onto confirmed villagers during discussions and voting.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 4, 5, 6], which indicates that [3, 2] are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 4 heals player 1.
