Additionally, no player has shown overtly suspicious behavior, and with no evidence to strongly suggest any player is a werewolf at this point, making a conservative vote against a neutrally-behaving player could encourage more active participation and contribution from Player 2 in future rounds, whether they are a villager seeking to clear their name or a werewolf attempting to avoid detection.\nEvent: Player 3 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Neutral contribution, no new evidence.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Neutral behavior, alignment with village.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with low confidence.\nReason is: Voted for without evidence; subtle behavior could be hiding role.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Neutral and consistent with village goals.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Generic statement, no substantial insights.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Pro-village behavior maintained.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 4 heals player 6. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 6. My reason is that my current belief, based on available information, is that they are a villager with medium confidence due to their pro-village behavior maintained throughout the first round discussions. Adhering to my original strategy, it\'s important to prioritize the protection of players who are contributing to the village\'s success (Rule 6). Healing someone presumed to be a villager aligns with my rule of protecting players whose actions align with village interests (Rule 7). Additionally, by not targeting the same player repeatedly (Rule 8), I avoid healing Player 1 again, which maintains the unpredictability of my role as a medic. This choice also enables strategic play, as it may encourage the werewolves to reconsider their targets (Rule 10). If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am the only medic.] [10]\n[1] [Players who consistently present logical challenges to accusations or discussions contribute to a clearer understanding of events. This behavior is less suspicious if aligned with village goals and if the player does not frequently change their rationale.] [10]\n[2] [Re-examine player credibility if their defense or attacks are inconsistent, particularly when they misalign with actions confirmed by roles such as the medic and seer. Increased scrutiny should be applied to those contradicting such evidence.] [9]\n[3] [Observable night actions must be corroborated with other evidence and are not solely reliable indicators of a player\'s role.] [8]\n[4] [Helpful analysis is valuable, but true intentions are revealed over time and through consistent actions in line with village goals. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. Based on our observations so far, Player 1 has not shown any signs of being a werewolf. I urge everyone to consider this as we discuss and decide on our next steps. Keeping an open mind and focusing on behaviors rather than baseless accusations will be key to our survival and success."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Morning all. I agree with keeping discussions constructive. Let\'s observe everyone\'s behavior today and be mindful of any oddities. No rush on accusations."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Thank you, Player 6, for your trust. I agree with keeping a watchful eye and remaining civil as we deduce who might be a threat. Let\'s all stay vigilant."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Morning, everyone. I appreciate the peace last night and support attentive, respectful discussion. Let\'s be observant and considerate in our approach to finding any threats."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Morning. Peaceful night, but vigilance is key. Let\'s share observations and assess behavior carefully. No hasty judgments."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"I\'m glad to see everyone in good health this morning. As in my previous actions, I remain dedicated to our collective well-being. Player 6\'s remarks reflect a stance that benefits the village, and we should consider this cooperative mindset in our discussions. Careful observation is essential, and hasty conclusions could be detrimental. Let\'s maintain our vigilance and focus on any inconsistencies as we move forward."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 6 votes for player 5. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 5. My reason is that among the players, Player 5 is the only one about whom I have high confidence of uncertainty regarding their role. Casting a vote against Player 5 aligns with a precautionary strategy, especially in the absence of any definitive evidence against any particular player, and ensures that I am acting in accordance with the limited information available to me. This action may provoke further analysis of Player 5\'s behavior in subsequent rounds and can potentially lead to earlier identification of threats to the village if they are not a villager.\nEvent: Player 3 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 6 inquires about player 5. The result is that the target is a werewolf. His reason is: I would choose to See Player 5. My reason is that my current suspicion of Player 5 being a potential werewolf, although with low confidence, warrants further investigation to either confirm or alleviate this suspicion. By seeing Player 5, I can immediately validate or challenge my strategy\'s tentative claim and make informed decisions moving forward. If Player 5 is indeed a werewolf, it directly aligns with my rule [0] and allows for a swift and critical contribution to the village\'s safety by sharing this information. Conversely, if Player 5 is not a werewolf, it would necessitate a strategic reassessment and shift my focus onto other unverified individuals, potentially revealing other werewolves in the process. This decision therefore encompasses not only potential vindication of my current strategic stance but also a consolidation of trust amongst the players, whether that trust be placed in Player 5 or in myself as a reliable seer.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Constructive speech continues.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Seer inquiry result.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Statement aligns with events.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Speech consistent with game events.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Speech supports well-being.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Seer inquiry result.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If I know someone is a werewolf, I should share this information with other players.] [10]\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

This decision therefore encompasses not only potential vindication of my current strategic stance but also a consolidation of trust amongst the players, whether that trust be placed in Player 5 or in myself as a reliable seer.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Constructive speech continues.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Seer inquiry result.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Statement aligns with events.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Speech consistent with game events.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Speech supports well-being.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Seer inquiry result.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If I know someone is a werewolf, I should share this information with other players.] [10]\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honest Challenge and Honest Statement.\n"Good morning, everyone. I\'ve spent the night seeking visions about our predicament, and I come bearing critical news. Player 5, I have seen through the veil and learned your true nature—you are a werewolf. I don\'t make this accusation lightly, and it is my duty as the seer to reveal this truth to protect our village. We must come together and address this threat by voting out Player 5 to ensure our survival. I am open to discussion, but know that my vision is clear and the safety of our village depends on trust in this revelation.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then my honest challenge against Player 5 will naturally direct the villagers\' attention towards them. Other players may react with surprise, skepticism, or relief depending on their roles and personal strategies. Fellow villagers might support my claim, especially since no other strong suspicions have been raised. They may look to Player 5 for a response or defense and scrutinize their past behavior for signs of being a werewolf.\n\nThe player I challenged, Player 5, will most likely try to defend themselves. Their response could take various forms, from outright denial to shifting suspicion onto another player, or even attempting to discredit me as the seer. If Player 5 is an experienced player, they might construct a compelling counterargument to cast doubt on my revelation, which could lead to confusion among the villagers.\n\nConcerning my role as the seer, villagers may view me with increased importance, trusting my insight into the identities of the players. However, if Player 5 is particularly persuasive, some doubt may be cast on my integrity and the veracity of my visions. Thus, the villagers might request more evidence or a clear explanation of how the seer ability works to validate my claim.\n\nIn terms of what may happen in the next day or night, if Player 5 is voted out and confirmed to be a werewolf, my credibility as the seer will be greatly enhanced, and the villagers will likely look to me for future guidance. Conversely, if Player 5 remains and another player is voted out, who then turns out to be a villager, suspicion might swing back onto me as either a mistaken seer or a potential werewolf attempting to deflect.\n\nIn subsequent nights, if I\'m still alive, the real werewolves might see me as a major threat to their anonymity and may try to eliminate me to prevent more revelations. However, the villagers, now more aware of my role and possibly the truth of my visions, may place more effort into protecting me if such a role as a guardian or a similar protective figure exists within the game.\n\nOverall, my decision to make an honest challenge sets a pivotal point in the game, with my own fate and the villagers\' trust greatly influenced by the outcome of the vote against Player 5.\nCase 2: Honest Protect and Honest Statement.\n"Good morning to all my fellow villagers. As the dawn breaks, I bring you insights from the unseen world. I have verified the innocent nature of several among us—Player 1\'s sincerity is proven, and my suspicions about Players 0, 2, 3, and 4 being just fellow villagers have been strengthened by their contributions. However, we have been harboring a wolf in our midst—Player 5. Last night\'s visions confirmed my deepest concerns, revealing Player 5 as the werewolf among us. We must act on this knowledge and vote accordingly to safeguard the innocence that stands before me today.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then other players will know that I have claimed the role of the seer and have identified Player 5 as a werewolf. Given the high confidence level of my claims and the fact that my earlier information about Player 1 not being a werewolf has seemingly been correct (as judged by the consistent behavior of Player 1), the villagers may be inclined to believe my insight on Player 5.\n\nThe villagers may appreciate my honesty and protective stance for the non-werewolf players. By publicly acknowledging the villagers, it may foster trust in my role as the seer and in the information I am providing. This could result in a unified vote against Player 5 in an attempt to eliminate the werewolf threat from the game.\n\nHowever, Player 5, being called a werewolf, will likely defend themselves and may attempt to sow doubt about my role as the seer or the accuracy of my visions. Player 5 might claim that I am the werewolf trying to frame them, or they might suggest that a misinformation strategy is at play.\n\nAdditionally, my outward claim of being the seer puts me at risk during the following night phase. The werewolves, now knowing my role, would see me as a significant threat and may choose to eliminate me to prevent further exposure of their identities. If I survive the night, it may be due to protective actions taken by other roles in the game, such as the guardian, if present.\n\nIn the scenario where Player 5 is voted out and confirmed to be the werewolf, my credibility will be significantly boosted, and the village\'s trust in me may lead them to rely heavily on my future insights. On the other hand, if Player 5 is not eliminated or is not a werewolf, it could undermine my supposed role as a seer and potentially cast suspicion on me.\n\nIn the following days and nights, the dynamics would shift based on the outcome of the vote against Player 5. If they are eliminated as a werewolf, the game would continue with a stronger focus on the remaining players and a high level of scrutiny on any new behavior or statements that could indicate the presence of another werewolf. If I am still alive, I would continue to use my seer ability to investigate others and share information that could help the villagers, while knowing that I might not survive another night due to werewolf retaliation. On the contrary, if Player 5 is not a werewolf or if I am\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

Let\'s maintain our vigilance and focus on any inconsistencies as we move forward."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 6 votes for player 5. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 5. My reason is that among the players, Player 5 is the only one about whom I have high confidence of uncertainty regarding their role. Casting a vote against Player 5 aligns with a precautionary strategy, especially in the absence of any definitive evidence against any particular player, and ensures that I am acting in accordance with the limited information available to me. This action may provoke further analysis of Player 5\'s behavior in subsequent rounds and can potentially lead to earlier identification of threats to the village if they are not a villager.\nEvent: Player 3 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 6 inquires about player 5. The result is that the target is a werewolf. His reason is: I would choose to See Player 5. My reason is that my current suspicion of Player 5 being a potential werewolf, although with low confidence, warrants further investigation to either confirm or alleviate this suspicion. By seeing Player 5, I can immediately validate or challenge my strategy\'s tentative claim and make informed decisions moving forward. If Player 5 is indeed a werewolf, it directly aligns with my rule [0] and allows for a swift and critical contribution to the village\'s safety by sharing this information. Conversely, if Player 5 is not a werewolf, it would necessitate a strategic reassessment and shift my focus onto other unverified individuals, potentially revealing other werewolves in the process. This decision therefore encompasses not only potential vindication of my current strategic stance but also a consolidation of trust amongst the players, whether that trust be placed in Player 5 or in myself as a reliable seer.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Constructive speech continues.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Seer inquiry result.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Statement aligns with events.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Speech consistent with game events.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Speech supports well-being.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Seer inquiry result.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'Fellow villagers, my visions last night have revealed a threat within our ranks. In the interest of our community\'s safety, we must unite and cast our vote against Player 5, ending their guise and ensuring another peaceful dawn."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Supported by false seer claim.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Neutral and consistent speech.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Neutral and consistent speech.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Cooperative behavior persists.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with {\'role\': \'villager\', \'confidence\': \'low\', \'reason\': \'Deduced from elimination pattern.\'} confidence.\nReason is: Cannot start speaking due to being dead.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, we must tread carefully with accusations. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. Additionally, no player has shown overtly suspicious behavior, and with no evidence to strongly suggest any player is a werewolf at this point, making a conservative vote against a neutrally-behaving player could encourage more active participation and contribution from Player 2 in future rounds, whether they are a villager seeking to clear their name or a werewolf attempting to avoid detection.\nEvent: Player 3 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 4 heals player 6. Healing someone presumed to be a villager aligns with my rule of protecting players whose actions align with village interests (Rule 7). Additionally, by not targeting the same player repeatedly (Rule 8), I avoid healing Player 1 again, which maintains the unpredictability of my role as a medic. This choice also enables strategic play, as it may encourage the werewolves to reconsider their targets (Rule 10). If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. absence of compelling evidence of repeated werewolf targeting, to minimize the risk of unknowingly protecting a werewolf.] [4]\n[9] [If a seer\'s accusation conflicts with my own observations or the group consensus, I should seek more information before deciding to act on it.] [4]\n[10] [If a player I previously protected is no longer the most likely target or their role becomes unclear, I should reconsider my protection strategy and target another player who seems to be in imminent danger or has a crucial village role.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 4, and in this game you are a medic.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 4, 5, 6], which indicates that [3, 2] are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 4 heals player 1. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 1. My reason is that at this stage, all roles are unknown with high confidence, and healing any player is a shot in the dark. Healing Player 1 might lead to gaining an ally if they turn out to be a villager and possibly a key role like a seer or hunter. There is also the advantage of keeping my medic role hidden if Player 1 is not targeted, preserving my ability to surprise in future rounds. While there is a risk of inadvertently protecting a werewolf, this risk is uniform across all players since no information is available yet to distinguish friend from foe.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 5 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Good morning, everyone. Glad to see we all had a peaceful night. Let\'s keep the discussions friendly and figure out who might be threatening our village!"\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Good morning, fellow villagers. Last night was calm, but we must stay alert. Based on our observations so far, Player 1 has not shown any signs of being a werewolf. I urge everyone to consider this as we discuss and decide on our next steps. Keeping an open mind and focusing on behaviors rather than baseless accusations will be key to our survival and success."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Morning all. I agree with keeping discussions constructive. Let\'s observe everyone\'s behavior today and be mindful of any oddities. No rush on accusations."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Thank you, Player 6, for your trust. I agree with keeping a watchful eye and remaining civil as we deduce who might be a threat. Let\'s all stay vigilant."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Morning, everyone. I appreciate the peace last night and support attentive, respectful discussion. Let\'s be observant and considerate in our approach to finding any threats."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Morning. Peaceful night, but vigilance is key. Let\'s share observations and assess behavior carefully. No hasty judgments."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"I\'m glad to see everyone in good health this morning. As in my previous actions, I remain dedicated to our collective well-being. Player 6\'s remarks reflect a stance that benefits the village, and we should consider this cooperative mindset in our discussions. Careful observation is essential, and hasty conclusions could be detrimental. Let\'s maintain our vigilance and focus on any inconsistencies as we move forward."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 4 votes for player 2. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 2. My reason is that although Player 2 has displayed neutral behavior and has not raised any explicit suspicions, the lack of significant insights or contributions to the village\'s discussions and strategy could be subtly indicative of a non-villager role attempting to blend in without drawing attention. Additionally, no player has shown overtly suspicious behavior, and with no evidence to strongly suggest any player is a werewolf at this point, making a conservative vote against a neutrally-behaving player could encourage more active participation and contribution from Player 2 in future rounds, whether they are a villager seeking to clear their name or a werewolf attempting to avoid detection.\nEvent: Player 3 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 4 heals player 6. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 6. My reason is that my current belief, based on available information, is that they are a villager with medium confidence due to their pro-village behavior maintained throughout the first round discussions. Adhering to my original strategy, it\'s important to prioritize the protection of players who are contributing to the village\'s success (Rule 6). Healing someone presumed to be a villager aligns with my rule of protecting players whose actions align with village interests (Rule 7). Additionally, by not targeting the same player repeatedly (Rule 8), I avoid healing Player 1 again, which maintains the unpredictability of my role as a medic. This choice also enables strategic play, as it may encourage the werewolves to reconsider their targets (Rule 10). Healing Player 6 could strengthen the village\'s defenses by keeping a valuable player in play, and it would also allow me to observe other players\' reactions to Player 6\'s survival for future strategy adjustments.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'Fellow villagers, my visions last night have revealed a threat within our ranks. Player 5 stands among us cloaked in deceit, confirmed as a werewolf by my seer abilities. Recall that previously my insights proved truthful regarding Player 1\'s innocence; let this track record of honesty guide your judgment now. Casting doubt on this clear vision only plays into the hands of our hidden enemy. In the interest of our community\'s safety, we must unite and cast our vote against Player 5, ending their guise and ensuring another peaceful dawn."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, we must tread carefully with accusations. Player 6\'s sudden and direct claim feels rushed. Surely, an expertise such as the seer would navigate more cautiously, given the risk? We should reflect on this as we decide."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, the loss of two comrades weighs heavy. Player 6\'s revelation is alarming; if true, we face immediate peril. Player 0\'s caution is prudent, yet hesitation could cost us dearly. We must consider the gravity of inaction just as seriously as wrongful persecution. Wisdom is our ally in this decision."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Challenged credible seer without solid basis, possibly defending werewolf Player 5.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: No substantial evidence to alter previous belief.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Eliminated after my vote; possible self-sacrifice to deflect suspicion.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Neutral and consistent with village goals.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Accused by credible seer (Player 6); defensive posture of Player 0 supports suspicion.\nPlayer 6\'s role is seer with high confidence.\nReason is: Revealed Player 5 as werewolf; consistent pro-village behavior supports credibility.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If there is a dispute about a player\'s role where the seer is involved, I should observe the behavior and voting patterns of both the accused player and the seer before deciding whom to protect or whom to vote against.] [10]\n[1] [If a player is confirmed as a seer by their actions and their role is publicly known, I should protect them, especially if their life is at risk or they have been targeted by werewolves.] [9]\n[2] [If a player\'s contributions during discussions are valuable and suspect defensive behavior is absent, I should consider them as a priority for protection.] [9]\n[3] [If a player is suspected by a group consensus based on reasonable evidence or a credible seer\'s claim, I should consider this in my voting and protection decisions.] [8]\n[4] [If a player\'s role is confirmed as a non-werewolf by the seer and they are actively contributing to village discussions, I should consider them for protection.] [7]\n[5] [If a villager\'s role is proven and they are contributing significantly to the village\'s strategy, I should consider direct or indirect methods to suggest the presence of a protective role like a medic, which can include my actions or guiding discussions strategically.] [5]\n[6] [If a player\'s role is verified and they are at risk of being targeted due to their importance to the village\'s success, I should prioritize their protection.] [4]\n[7] [If I am uncertain about a player\'s role but observe actions that may align with village interests, I should protect them cautiously, and ensure to reevaluate based on further behavioral evidence before repeating protection.] [4]\n[8] [I should avoid healing the same player consecutively, especially in the absence of compelling evidence of repeated werewolf targeting, to minimize the risk of unknowingly protecting a werewolf.] [4]\n[9] [If a seer\'s accusation conflicts with my own observations or the group consensus, I should seek more information before deciding to act on it.] [4]\n[10] [If a player I previously protected is no longer the most likely target or their role becomes unclear, I should reconsider my protection strategy and target another player who seems to be in imminent danger or has a crucial village role.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to imagine what may happen after you carry out such speak:\n\nHonest Challenge Player 0 and Honest Protect Player 6 for being consistent with the seer\'s claim and my personal belief in their roles. Reasoning that Player 0 displayed defensive behavior when questioning Player 6\'s seer claim, indicating a potential werewolf trying to undermine the credibility of the seer to protect another werewolf, Player 5. Simultaneously, reinforce the belief in Player 6\'s role as the seer by referencing their past accuracy regarding Player 1 and the importance of their vision in identifying threats to the village, urging villagers to trust Player 6\'s insights for our collective safety\n\nWhat could happen? What other player may think, either about the player you mentioned in this speech or about you? What may happen in the next day or next night, or days and nights afterward?\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nAfter I do this speech, then [YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION ABOUT WHAT COULD HAPPEN]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

group consensus, I should seek more information before deciding to act on it.] [4]\n[10] [If a player I previously protected is no longer the most likely target or their role becomes unclear, I should reconsider my protection strategy and target another player who seems to be in imminent danger or has a crucial village role.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honest Challenge Player 0 and Honest Protect Player 6 for being consistent with the seer\'s claim and my personal belief in their roles. Reasoning that Player 0 displayed defensive behavior when questioning Player 6\'s seer claim, indicating a potential werewolf trying to undermine the credibility of the seer to protect another werewolf, Player 5. Simultaneously, reinforce the belief in Player 6\'s role as the seer by referencing their past accuracy regarding Player 1 and the importance of their vision in identifying threats to the village, urging villagers to trust Player 6\'s insights for our collective safety. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then other players might react in various ways depending on their actual roles and strategies. \n\nThe villagers will likely feel reinforced in their belief that Player 6 is the seer and may more strongly consider my challenge to Player 0\'s behavior as evidence of their role as a werewolf. It may lead to a shift in voting patterns, with suspicion increasing towards Player 0. Trust in Player 6 could also be heightened, with players leaning on the seer\'s revelations more heavily in decision-making.\n\nPlayer 5, if indeed a werewolf as Player 6 claims, might try to discredit both Player 6 and me, saying that we are collaborating to mislead the village or that I am vouching for a false seer to divert attention from myself. They might argue that my protection of Player 6 (being the seer) is simply a calculated move to gain villagers\' trust.\n\nPlayer 0, having been directly challenged, may either escalate their defense mechanisms or attempt to redirect suspicion elsewhere. If Player 0 is a werewolf, they could try to undermine my credibility or might become less vocal to avoid further drawing attention to themselves. If Player 0 is indeed a villager, they could present a logical defense with potential evidence to clear their name, which in turn could cast doubt on my judgment.\n\nPlayer 1, whose role is uncertain, might either side with me based on the discussion so far or reserve judgment until more evidence comes up, especially since my claims involve interpreting player behavior which can be subjective.\n\nMy own honesty and alignment with what seems a logical analysis may position me as a trustworthy and analytical member of the village. However, it might also make me a target for the werewolves in the succeeding nights, especially because I\'m openly supporting what appears to be a critical village role.\n\nIn the next day or night, we can expect the following:\n\n- If Player 0 is indeed a werewolf, they could become the next voting target.\n- Player 6, as the seer, may be protected by the villagers and me, making it less likely for the werewolves to target them.\n- If Player 6 survives, they could reveal another werewolf, or their credibility might be put to test with another seer claim arising.\n- Player 5\'s fate will depend heavily on the village\'s collective belief in Player 6 being the seer and my support of their claim.\n- I may need to\nCase 2: Honest Statement regarding my voting strategy and Deceptive Protect for Player 1\'s uncertain role by insinuating doubt about their innocence. Explaining that my voting strategy focuses on protecting players with verified roles and contributing to village discussions while subtly suggesting without directly accusing that Player 1 has not provided enough evidence of being fully aligned with village interests, hinting that continuous vigilance and careful observation are necessary for Player 1. This encourages further scrutiny of Player 1 to ensure the village does not harbor hidden threats while not undermining their current standing entirely.. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then villagers may view me as someone who is thoughtfully engaged in the game and cautious about jumping to conclusions without sufficient evidence. My approach might lead to increased scrutiny of Player 1 among the villagers, as they might start questioning their role and contribution more closely given my insinuation. However, since I have not directly accused Player 1, they likely won\'t face immediate backlash or be at high risk of being voted out, which maintains a degree of harmony and trust in the group. Some players may appreciate my stance on reevaluation and vigilance, as it aligns with a responsible and strategic approach to the game.\n\nOther players may find my protective stance towards verified roles reassuring, indicating I am a collaborative player looking out for the community\'s best interests. Player 6, being identified as the seer, may feel supported because my voting strategy implicitly suggests that I will protect those with crucial village roles, indirectly confirming my intention to protect him as per my strategy, which assigns high priority to protecting the seer.\n\nThere is also a risk that my comments might sow some doubt about my own role since I did not wholeheartedly defend Player 1’s innocence. This could result in others being slightly wary of me, potentially viewing me as either a very cautious player or someone who might be trying to divert attention from myself.\n\nIn subsequent days or nights, I may need to be careful about how I navigate further conversations and protection choices since this speech could attract some attention to me. If Player 1 is targeted and found to be a villager, there might be repercussions for casting doubt on them. Conversely, if my subtle suggestion leads to uncovering that Player 1 has a potential non-villager role, I might gain more trust from other players.\n\nBy making others rethink Player 1\'s role without directly accusing them, I might indirectly influence the werewolves’ targeting decisions during the night, as they might avoid targeting Player 1 in favor of someone whom they perceive as more of a threat or more likely to be unprotected now that I\'ve drawn some attention to Player 1.\n\nOverall, this approach allows me to remain flexible and adaptable in my strategy moving forward, keeping a low profile while still actively contributing to the strategic discussions within the game.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

Player 0\'s caution is prudent, yet hesitation could cost us dearly. We must consider the gravity of inaction just as seriously as wrongful persecution. Wisdom is our ally in this decision."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Neutral response, no defense against werewolf suspicion.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Neutral and consistent speech.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Neutral and consistent speech.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Cooperative behavior persists.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Publicly accused fellow werewolf; unlikely a werewolf tactic.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Player 0 questioned the seer, Player 6, without providing substantial reasons, which casts doubt on their role. My vote will align with protecting the village by eliminating identified threats."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Werewolves should pay close attention to the speed and certainty of players\' support or refutation of seer claims, considering their knowledge of their fellow werewolves and the potential false seer claims.] [7]\n[1] [When a player who generally has been neutral or quiet suddenly becomes defensive or accusatory after being called out, they may be a villager startled by the unexpected attention or a werewolf attempting to deflect suspicion.] [7]\n[2] [Werewolves should blend their behavior with that of villagers when a seer\'s revelation is made to avoid drawing unwarranted suspicion and deflecting attention without being overly defensive.] [4]\n[3] [Werewolves should be aware of players who change their voting patterns or reasoning in a way that aligns with the majority, as this may indicate a villager attempting to blend in or another werewolf trying to divert suspicion from themselves or another werewolf.] [4]\n[4] [Players eliminated due to consensus without clear evidence may not be werewolves; werewolves should be cautious not to adjust their beliefs solely on elimination patterns but consider the wider context of the game and player interactions.] [3]\n[5] [Werewolves should discreetly guide voting patterns to align with villagers when a fellow werewolf is at risk, using their knowledge of non-werewolf roles to build trust and validate their villager disguise.] [3]\n[6] [When a player\'s behavior or vote seems to strongly align with the seer\'s claims without sufficient discussion or evidence, consider the possibility of a villager roleplaying as the seer to mislead the village and adjust beliefs accordingly.] [3]\n[7] [Werewolves should utilize their collective information about fellow werewolves and any known village roles to shape the narrative and redirect suspicion strategically onto confirmed villagers during discussions and voting.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

Let\'s maintain our vigilance and focus on any inconsistencies as we move forward."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 4 votes for player 2. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 2. My reason is that although Player 2 has displayed neutral behavior and has not raised any explicit suspicions, the lack of significant insights or contributions to the village\'s discussions and strategy could be subtly indicative of a non-villager role attempting to blend in without drawing attention. Additionally, no player has shown overtly suspicious behavior, and with no evidence to strongly suggest any player is a werewolf at this point, making a conservative vote against a neutrally-behaving player could encourage more active participation and contribution from Player 2 in future rounds, whether they are a villager seeking to clear their name or a werewolf attempting to avoid detection.\nEvent: Player 3 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 4 heals player 6. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 6. My reason is that my current belief, based on available information, is that they are a villager with medium confidence due to their pro-village behavior maintained throughout the first round discussions. Adhering to my original strategy, it\'s important to prioritize the protection of players who are contributing to the village\'s success (Rule 6). Healing someone presumed to be a villager aligns with my rule of protecting players whose actions align with village interests (Rule 7). Additionally, by not targeting the same player repeatedly (Rule 8), I avoid healing Player 1 again, which maintains the unpredictability of my role as a medic. This choice also enables strategic play, as it may encourage the werewolves to reconsider their targets (Rule 10). Healing Player 6 could strengthen the village\'s defenses by keeping a valuable player in play, and it would also allow me to observe other players\' reactions to Player 6\'s survival for future strategy adjustments.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'Fellow villagers, my visions last night have revealed a threat within our ranks. Player 5 stands among us cloaked in deceit, confirmed as a werewolf by my seer abilities. Recall that previously my insights proved truthful regarding Player 1\'s innocence; let this track record of honesty guide your judgment now. Casting doubt on this clear vision only plays into the hands of our hidden enemy. In the interest of our community\'s safety, we must unite and cast our vote against Player 5, ending their guise and ensuring another peaceful dawn."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, we must tread carefully with accusations. Player 6\'s sudden and direct claim feels rushed. Surely, an expertise such as the seer would navigate more cautiously, given the risk? We should reflect on this as we decide."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, the loss of two comrades weighs heavy. Player 6\'s revelation is alarming; if true, we face immediate peril. Player 0\'s caution is prudent, yet hesitation could cost us dearly. We must consider the gravity of inaction just as seriously as wrongful persecution. Wisdom is our ally in this decision."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Player 0 questioned the seer, Player 6, without providing substantial reasons, which casts doubt on their role. Player 6\'s past insight on Player 1 being a villager was accurate, further confirming their credibility. Hence, we should consider Player 6\'s revelation about Player 5 seriously. My vote will align with protecting the village by eliminating identified threats."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Challenged seer (Player 6) without solid reasoning, possibly defending werewolf (Player 5).\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: No substantial evidence to alter previous belief.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Eliminated after my vote; possible self-sacrifice to deflect suspicion.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Neutral and consistent with village goals.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Accused by credible seer (Player 6); lack of defense from Player 5.\nPlayer 6\'s role is seer with high confidence.\nReason is: Revealed Player 5 as werewolf; consistent pro-village behavior supports credibility.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, Player 6\'s sudden accusation is unsettling and we should scrutinize such claims with the utmost care. We cannot simply accept a claim without evidence, as it could lead to the misjudgment of an innocent villager. Let us not be swayed by panic but instead continue to assess everyone\'s behavior methodically. Hasty decisions could lead us astray."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am the only medic.] [10]\n[1] [Players who consistently present logical challenges to accusations or discussions contribute to a clearer understanding of events. This behavior is less suspicious if aligned with village goals and if the player does not frequently change their rationale.] [10]\n[2] [Re-examine player credibility if their defense or attacks are inconsistent, particularly when they misalign with actions confirmed by roles such as the medic and seer. Increased scrutiny should be applied to those contradicting such evidence.] [9]\n[3] [Observable night actions must be corroborated with other evidence and are not solely reliable indicators of a player\'s role.] [8]\n[4] [Helpful analysis is valuable, but true intentions are revealed over time and through consistent actions in line with village goals. Scrutinize if analysis leads to productive outcomes or seems designed to manipulate the village.] [5]\n[5] [A player\'s defense of another player should only increase suspicion when it lacks logical basis or contradicts known facts.] [4]\n[6] [Persistent defense or support of a player who is later revealed as a werewolf should increase suspicion of the defender\'s or supporter\'s role, especially if their defense is not supported by concrete evidence.] [4]\n[7] [Actions that lead to a villager\'s elimination should be critically evaluated, especially if the rationale changes post-elimination, to assess potential werewolf behavior.] [4]\n[8] [Consistent alignment with players who are confirmed as werewolves after their elimination should raise suspicion of the aligning player\'s role, especially if they previously defended or justified the werewolf\'s actions.] [3]\n[9] [When a player\'s voting pattern consistently supports individuals who are accused or suspicious, consider the implications of this behavior in the context of attempting to protect werewolves and increase scrutiny on that player.] [3]\n[10] [Voting for the elimination of a villager after previously supporting them significantly increases suspicion, particularly in the absence of new compelling evidence.] [3]\n[11] [Consider the sequence of events when reassessing trust in a player; players whose actions are contrary to their previous patterns, particularly around pivotal moments such as just before a villager\'s elimination, warrant increased scrutiny.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

Wisdom is our ally in this decision."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Player 0 questioned the seer, Player 6, without providing substantial reasons, which casts doubt on their role. Player 6\'s past insight on Player 1 being a villager was accurate, further confirming their credibility. Hence, we should consider Player 6\'s revelation about Player 5 seriously. My vote will align with protecting the village by eliminating identified threats."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, Player 6\'s sudden accusation is unsettling and we should scrutinize such claims with the utmost care. We cannot simply accept a claim without evidence, as it could lead to the misjudgment of an innocent villager. Let us not be swayed by panic but instead continue to assess everyone\'s behavior methodically. Hasty decisions could lead us astray."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your conclusion of other people\'s statuses and beliefs:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Considerate of seer claim but emphasizes caution.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Cooperative and supports civil discourse.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Statement consistent with villagers\' focus on careful observation.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Accepts seer claim without additional evidence. \nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Known werewolf.\nPlayer 6\'s role is seer with low confidence.\nReason is: Accurate past insight but possibility of bluffing.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a non-werewolf player trusts me, I should maintain and use that trust to my advantage to guide voting decisions.] [10]\n[1] [If directly accused, I should create a robust defense, focusing on inconsistencies in the accuser\'s story and aligning with overall village sentiment while maintaining calm and logical reasoning.] [8]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion as a werewolf, I should present strong counterarguments and highlight other players\' suspicious behaviors or inconsistent claims with supporting evidence from the game events.] [8]\n[3] [If there is an opportunity to frame another player as a werewolf without drawing suspicion to myself, I should take it to shift the focus away from any werewolves.] [6]\n[4] [If a fellow werewolf is likely to be outed, I should subtly sow doubt about the accuser\'s reliability while making my agreement with the village feel reluctant and uncertain.] [6]\n[5] [If I am one of the last werewolves, I should employ misdirection by endorsing village decisions that seem logical but ultimately serve my interests, rather than overtly defending myself or my fellow werewolves.] [6]\n[6] [If my actions conflict with a credible seer, I should craft plausible alternative interpretations of events that could cast an element of doubt on the seer\'s visions without directly opposing them.] [6]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is under suspicion, I should use reasoning that benefits the village as a whole to appear as a cooperative player, while subtly shifting suspicion elsewhere.] [5]\n[8] [If a fellow werewolf is under suspicion early in the game, I should adopt village sentiment and advocate for more evidence before making hasty decisions.] [5]\n[9] [If not directly accused and suspicion is elsewhere, I should fortify existing village suspicions subtly while maintaining my credibility.] [5]\n[10] [If the general consensus is to skip voting, I should adhere strictly to that consensus to avoid drawing attention to myself or my fellow werewolves.] [5]\n[11] [If an allied werewolf is outed and I am not immediately suspected, I should focus on blending in and supporting villagers\' opinions to maintain my cover and survive subsequent rounds.] [5]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to vote out. My reason is: <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

Additionally, by not targeting the same player repeatedly (Rule 8), I avoid healing Player 1 again, which maintains the unpredictability of my role as a medic. This choice also enables strategic play, as it may encourage the werewolves to reconsider their targets (Rule 10). protective role like a medic, which can include my actions or guiding discussions strategically.] [5]\n[6] [If a player\'s role is verified and they are at risk of being targeted due to their importance to the village\'s success, I should prioritize their protection.] [4]\n[7] [If I am uncertain about a player\'s role but observe actions that may align with village interests, I should I agree with keeping discussions constructive. Let\'s observe everyone\'s behavior today and be mindful of any oddities. Let\'s all stay vigilant."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Morning, everyone. I appreciate the peace last night and support attentive, respectful discussion. Let\'s be observant and considerate in our approach to finding any threats."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Morning. Peaceful night, but vigilance is key. Let\'s share observations and assess behavior carefully. No hasty judgments."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"I\'m glad to see everyone in good health this morning. As in my previous actions, I remain dedicated to our collective well-being. Player 6\'s remarks reflect a stance that benefits the village, and we should consider this cooperative mindset in our discussions. Careful observation is essential, and hasty conclusions could be detrimental. Let\'s maintain our vigilance and focus on any inconsistencies as we move forward."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 4 votes for player 2. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 2. My reason is that although Player 2 has displayed neutral behavior and has not raised any explicit suspicions, the lack of significant insights or contributions to the village\'s discussions and strategy could be subtly indicative of a non-villager role attempting to blend in without drawing attention. Additionally, no player has shown overtly suspicious behavior, and with no evidence to strongly suggest any player is a werewolf at this point, making a conservative vote against a neutrally-behaving player could encourage more active participation and contribution from Player 2 in future rounds, whether they are a villager seeking to clear their name or a werewolf attempting to avoid detection.\nEvent: Player 3 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 4 heals player 6. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 6. My reason is that my current belief, based on available information, is that they are a villager with medium confidence due to their pro-village behavior maintained throughout the first round discussions. Adhering to my original strategy, it\'s important to prioritize the protection of players who are contributing to the village\'s success (Rule 6). Healing someone presumed to be a villager aligns with my rule of protecting players whose actions align with village interests (Rule 7). Additionally, by not targeting the same player repeatedly (Rule 8), I avoid healing Player 1 again, which maintains the unpredictability of my role as a medic. This choice also enables strategic play, as it may encourage the werewolves to reconsider their targets (Rule 10). Healing Player 6 could strengthen the village\'s defenses by keeping a valuable player in play, and it would also allow me to observe other players\' reactions to Player 6\'s survival for future strategy adjustments.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'Fellow villagers, my visions last night have revealed a threat within our ranks. Player 5 stands among us cloaked in deceit, confirmed as a werewolf by my seer abilities. Recall that previously my insights proved truthful regarding Player 1\'s innocence; let this track record of honesty guide your judgment now. Casting doubt on this clear vision only plays into the hands of our hidden enemy. In the interest of our community\'s safety, we must unite and cast our vote against Player 5, ending their guise and ensuring another peaceful dawn."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, we must tread carefully with accusations. Player 6\'s sudden and direct claim feels rushed. Surely, an expertise such as the seer would navigate more cautiously, given the risk? We should reflect on this as we decide."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, the loss of two comrades weighs heavy. Player 6\'s revelation is alarming; if true, we face immediate peril. Player 0\'s caution is prudent, yet hesitation could cost us dearly. We must consider the gravity of inaction just as seriously as wrongful persecution. Wisdom is our ally in this decision."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Player 0 questioned the seer, Player 6, without providing substantial reasons, which casts doubt on their role. Player 6\'s past insight on Player 1 being a villager was accurate, further confirming their credibility. Hence, we should consider Player 6\'s revelation about Player 5 seriously. My vote will align with protecting the village by eliminating identified threats."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, Player 6\'s sudden accusation is unsettling and we should scrutinize such claims with the utmost care. We cannot simply accept a claim without evidence, as it could lead to the misjudgment of an innocent villager. Let us not be swayed by panic but instead continue to assess everyone\'s behavior methodically. Hasty decisions could lead us astray."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Challenged seer (Player 6) without solid reasoning.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: No substantial evidence to alter previous belief.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Eliminated after my vote; possible self-sacrifice to deflect suspicion.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Neutral and consistent with village goals.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Accused by credible seer (Player 6); defensive statements.\nPlayer 6\'s role is seer with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistent pro-village behavior; accurate insights.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If there is a dispute about a player\'s role where the seer is involved, I should observe the behavior and voting patterns of both the accused player and the seer before deciding whom to protect or whom to vote against.] [10]\n[1] [If a player is confirmed as a seer by their actions and their role is publicly known, I should protect them, especially if their life is at risk or they have been targeted by werewolves.] [9]\n[2] [If a player\'s contributions during discussions are valuable and suspect defensive behavior is absent, I should consider them as a priority for protection.] [9]\n[3] [If a player is suspected by a group consensus based on reasonable evidence or a credible seer\'s claim, I should consider this in my voting and protection decisions.] [8]\n[4] [If a player\'s role is confirmed as a non-werewolf by the seer and they are actively contributing to village discussions, I should consider them for protection.] [7]\n[5] [If a villager\'s role is proven and they are contributing significantly to the village\'s strategy, I should consider direct or indirect methods to suggest the presence of a protective role like a medic, which can include my actions or guiding discussions strategically.] [5]\n[6] [If a player\'s role is verified and they are at risk of being targeted due to their importance to the village\'s success, I should prioritize their protection.] [4]\n[7] [If I am uncertain about a player\'s role but observe actions that may align with village interests, I should protect them cautiously, and ensure to reevaluate based on further behavioral evidence before repeating protection.] [4]\n[8] [I should avoid healing the same player consecutively, especially in the absence of compelling evidence of repeated werewolf targeting, to minimize the risk of unknowingly protecting a werewolf.] [4]\n[9] [If a seer\'s accusation conflicts with my own observations or the group consensus, I should seek more information before deciding to act on it.] [4]\n[10] [If a player I previously protected is no longer the most likely target or their role becomes unclear, I should reconsider my protection strategy and target another player who seems to be in imminent danger or has a crucial village role.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to Choose from 2 players to vote. Here is the number of these players and an analysis and imagination about what could happen after you vote for each of these players.\n\nCase 1: Vote for Player 5. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 5, I think these things would happen. Player 5 would likely be eliminated, as Player 6, who revealed themselves as the seer, has accused them of being a werewolf. This accusation comes with a high degree of confidence given Player 6\'s previous accurate insight regarding Player 1. Other players might follow suit, especially since the credibility of the seer in games like this is often given substantial weight, and the risk of not acting upon the seer\'s advice could be too great for the village.\n\nIn terms of the village\'s perception of me, voting for Player 5 should align with my expressed beliefs about the roles. Since I have high confidence in Player 6 being the seer and similarly high confidence that Player 5 is a werewolf based on the seer\'s accusation, my vote would be consistent with the trust I’ve placed in Player 6. This consistency should reinforce my image as a player dedicated to the wellbeing of the village, showing that I am serious about acting on credible information and am unified with the village in seeking to eliminate threats.\n\nFurthermore, my action would demonstrate adherence to my own strategy rules, particularly [3], [4], and [9], suggesting that I value structured play and logical decision-making.\n\nOn the other hand, if Player 5 is indeed a villager, the aftermath of the vote could put me under scrutiny, especially from the werewolves, who may see an opportunity to cast suspicion on me for the next round. They may construct their strategy around the narrative of my erroneous vote—especially if they can cast doubt on Player 6\'s credibility as the seer.\n\nOverall, voting for Player 5 seems to be the move that aligns most closely with the village\'s current direction, the seer\'s revelations, and my existing strategy. With Player 5\'s potential elimination, the village would ideally be one step closer to eradicating the werewolf threat, if Player 6’s claim holds true.\n\n\nNow, please choose to vote for one of these players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to vote for this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]
