This decision therefore encompasses not only potential vindication of my current strategic stance but also a consolidation of trust amongst the players, whether that trust be placed in Player 5 or in myself as a reliable seer.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'Fellow villagers, my visions last night have revealed a threat within our ranks. Player 5 stands among us cloaked in deceit, confirmed as a werewolf by my seer abilities. Recall that previously my insights proved truthful regarding Player 1\'s innocence; let this track record of honesty guide your judgment now. Casting doubt on this clear vision only plays into the hands of our hidden enemy. In the interest of our community\'s safety, we must unite and cast our vote against Player 5, ending their guise and ensuring another peaceful dawn."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, we must tread carefully with accusations. Player 6\'s sudden and direct claim feels rushed. Surely, an expertise such as the seer would navigate more cautiously, given the risk? We should reflect on this as we decide."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, the loss of two comrades weighs heavy. Player 6\'s revelation is alarming; if true, we face immediate peril. Player 0\'s caution is prudent, yet hesitation could cost us dearly. We must consider the gravity of inaction just as seriously as wrongful persecution. Wisdom is our ally in this decision."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Player 0 questioned the seer, Player 6, without providing substantial reasons, which casts doubt on their role. Player 6\'s past insight on Player 1 being a villager was accurate, further confirming their credibility. Hence, we should consider Player 6\'s revelation about Player 5 seriously. My vote will align with protecting the village by eliminating identified threats."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, Player 6\'s sudden accusation is unsettling and we should scrutinize such claims with the utmost care. We cannot simply accept a claim without evidence, as it could lead to the misjudgment of an innocent villager. Let us not be swayed by panic but instead continue to assess everyone\'s behavior methodically. Hasty decisions could lead us astray."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Expressed skepticism about a confirmed seer without justification.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Supported consideration of seer\'s revelation, no anomaly in speech.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Statement aligns with events.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Speech consistent with game events.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Supported the seer\'s claim, consistent with previous behavior.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed by seer vision, defensive response to accusation.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If I know someone is a werewolf, I should share this information with other players.] [10]\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 1 players you want to vote out. My reason is that Player 6, who has been identified as the seer with high confidence and has previously provided accurate information about another player\'s role, has accused Player 5 of being a werewolf. If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am the only medic.] [10]\n[1] [Players who consistently present logical challenges to accusations or discussions contribute to a clearer understanding of events. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. His reason is: I vote for Player 5. My reason is: Player 6\'s claim of being a seer has gained some support in the village. Voting against this claim might cast suspicion on me. With Player 5 already under heavy suspicion, aligning with the village on this vote is the safest option for now. It follows rule [8] which advises taking the village sentiment into account before making hasty decisions and rule [9] which suggests fortifying existing suspicions while maintaining credibility.\nEvent: Player 5 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your conclusion of other people\'s statuses and beliefs:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Emphasizes caution and considers impact of actions.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Cooperative and supports civil discourse.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Statement consistent with villagers\' focus on careful observation.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Quick to trust player 6\'s seer claim, aligns with the majority.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Known werewolf.\nPlayer 6\'s role is seer with low confidence.\nReason is: Previous insight seemingly accurate but could be a bluff.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a non-werewolf player trusts me, I should maintain and use that trust to my advantage to guide voting decisions.] [10]\n[1] [If directly accused, I should create a robust defense, focusing on inconsistencies in the accuser\'s story and aligning with overall village sentiment while maintaining calm and logical reasoning.] [8]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion as a werewolf, I should present strong counterarguments and highlight other players\' suspicious behaviors or inconsistent claims with supporting evidence from the game events.] [8]\n[3] [If there is an opportunity to frame another player as a werewolf without drawing suspicion to myself, I should take it to shift the focus away from any werewolves.] [6]\n[4] [If a fellow werewolf is likely to be outed, I should subtly sow doubt about the accuser\'s reliability while making my agreement with the village feel reluctant and uncertain.] [6]\n[5] [If I am one of the last werewolves, I should employ misdirection by endorsing village decisions that seem logical but ultimately serve my interests, rather than overtly defending myself or my fellow werewolves.] [6]\n[6] [If my actions conflict with a credible seer, I should craft plausible alternative interpretations of events that could cast an element of doubt on the seer\'s visions without directly opposing them.] [6]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is under suspicion, I should use reasoning that benefits the village as a whole to appear as a cooperative player, while subtly shifting suspicion elsewhere.] [5]\n[8] [If a fellow werewolf is under suspicion early in the game, I should adopt village sentiment and advocate for more evidence before making hasty decisions.] [5]\n[9] [If not directly accused and suspicion is elsewhere, I should fortify existing village suspicions subtly while maintaining my credibility.] [5]\n[10] [If the general consensus is to skip voting, I should adhere strictly to that consensus to avoid drawing attention to myself or my fellow werewolves.] [5]\n[11] [If an allied werewolf is outed and I am not immediately suspected, I should focus on blending in and supporting villagers\' opinions to maintain my cover and survive subsequent rounds.] [5]\n\n\n2.Todo&Requirements:\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to kill. \n\nYou should make your own decision but consider your teammates\' advices. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nI choose to kill Player <NUMBER>. My reason is: <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease provide your operation based on the above requirements.\n'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are player 4, and in this game you are a medic.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 4, 6], which indicates that [3, 2, 5] are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 4 heals player 1. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 1. My reason is that at this stage, all roles are unknown with high confidence, and healing any player is a shot in the dark. Healing Player 1 might lead to gaining an ally if they turn out to be a villager and possibly a key role like a seer or hunter. There is also the advantage of keeping my medic role hidden if Player 1 is not targeted, preserving my ability to surprise in future rounds. While there is a risk of inadvertently protecting a werewolf, this risk is uniform across all players since no information is available yet to distinguish friend from foe.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 5 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Good morning, everyone. Glad to see we all had a peaceful night. Let\'s keep the discussions friendly and figure out who might be threatening our village!"\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Good morning, fellow villagers. Last night was calm, but we must stay alert. Based on our observations so far, Player 1 has not shown any signs of being a werewolf. I urge everyone to consider this as we discuss and decide on our next steps. Keeping an open mind and focusing on behaviors rather than baseless accusations will be key to our survival and success."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Morning all. I agree with keeping discussions constructive. Let\'s observe everyone\'s behavior today and be mindful of any oddities. No rush on accusations."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Thank you, Player 6, for your trust. I agree with keeping a watchful eye and remaining civil as we deduce who might be a threat. Let\'s all stay vigilant."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Morning, everyone. I appreciate the peace last night and support attentive, respectful discussion. Let\'s be observant and considerate in our approach to finding any threats."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Morning. Peaceful night, but vigilance is key. Let\'s share observations and assess behavior carefully. No hasty judgments."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"I\'m glad to see everyone in good health this morning. As in my previous actions, I remain dedicated to our collective well-being. Player 6\'s remarks reflect a stance that benefits the village, and we should consider this cooperative mindset in our discussions. Careful observation is essential, and hasty conclusions could be detrimental. Let\'s maintain our vigilance and focus on any inconsistencies as we move forward."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 4 votes for player 2. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 2. My reason is that although Player 2 has displayed neutral behavior and has not raised any explicit suspicions, the lack of significant insights or contributions to the village\'s discussions and strategy could be subtly indicative of a non-villager role attempting to blend in without drawing attention. Additionally, no player has shown overtly suspicious behavior, and with no evidence to strongly suggest any player is a werewolf at this point, making a conservative vote against a neutrally-behaving player could encourage more active participation and contribution from Player 2 in future rounds, whether they are a villager seeking to clear their name or a werewolf attempting to avoid detection.\nEvent: Player 3 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 4 heals player 6. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 6. My reason is that my current belief, based on available information, is that they are a villager with medium confidence due to their pro-village behavior maintained throughout the first round discussions. Adhering to my original strategy, it\'s important to prioritize the protection of players who are contributing to the village\'s success (Rule 6). Healing someone presumed to be a villager aligns with my rule of protecting players whose actions align with village interests (Rule 7). Additionally, by not targeting the same player repeatedly (Rule 8), I avoid healing Player 1 again, which maintains the unpredictability of my role as a medic. This choice also enables strategic play, as it may encourage the werewolves to reconsider their targets (Rule 10). Healing Player 6 could strengthen the village\'s defenses by keeping a valuable player in play, and it would also allow me to observe other players\' reactions to Player 6\'s survival for future strategy adjustments.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'Fellow villagers, my visions last night have revealed a threat within our ranks. Player 5 stands among us cloaked in deceit, confirmed as a werewolf by my seer abilities. Recall that previously my insights proved truthful regarding Player 1\'s innocence; let this track record of honesty guide your judgment now. Casting doubt on this clear vision only plays into the hands of our hidden enemy. In the interest of our community\'s safety, we must unite and cast our vote against Player 5, ending their guise and ensuring another peaceful dawn."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, we must tread carefully with accusations. Player 6\'s sudden and direct claim feels rushed. Surely, an expertise such as the seer would navigate more cautiously, given the risk? We should reflect on this as we decide."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, the loss of two comrades weighs heavy. Player 6\'s revelation is alarming; if true, we face immediate peril. Player 0\'s caution is prudent, yet hesitation could cost us dearly. We must consider the gravity of inaction just as seriously as wrongful persecution. Wisdom is our ally in this decision."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Player 0 questioned the seer, Player 6, without providing substantial reasons, which casts doubt on their role. Player 6\'s past insight on Player 1 being a villager was accurate, further confirming their credibility. Hence, we should consider Player 6\'s revelation about Player 5 seriously. My vote will align with protecting the village by eliminating identified threats."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, Player 6\'s sudden accusation is unsettling and we should scrutinize such claims with the utmost care. We cannot simply accept a claim without evidence, as it could lead to the misjudgment of an innocent villager. Let us not be swayed by panic but instead continue to assess everyone\'s behavior methodically. Hasty decisions could lead us astray."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 4 votes for player 5. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 5. My reason is that Player 6, who has been identified as the seer with high confidence and has previously provided accurate information about another player\'s role, has accused Player 5 of being a werewolf. By voting for Player 5, I am aligning with the seer\'s guidance, which is a critical strategy in protecting the village from the werewolf threat, as outlined in my strategy rules [0], [1], [3], and [9]. This action supports the structured play and logical decision-making that my strategy emphasizes. Acting on the seer\'s credible accusation aligns with the best interests of the village and my role as a medic dedicated to the village\'s survival.\nEvent: Player 5 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Challenged seer without solid reasoning; defensive behavior misaligned with village goals.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: No contradiction in statements; aligned with seer\'s information.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Eliminated after my vote; possible self-sacrifice to deflect suspicion.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Neutral and consistent with village goals.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Accused by credible seer (Player 6); defensive statements.\nPlayer 6\'s role is seer with high confidence.\nReason is: Accusation led to the elimination of a werewolf; consistent pro-village behavior.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If there is a dispute about a player\'s role where the seer is involved, I should observe the behavior and voting patterns of both the accused player and the seer before deciding whom to protect or whom to vote against.] [10]\n[1] [If a player is confirmed as a seer by their actions and their role is publicly known, I should protect them, especially if their life is at risk or they have been targeted by werewolves.] [9]\n[2] [If a player\'s contributions during discussions are valuable and suspect defensive behavior is absent, I should consider them as a priority for protection.] [9]\n[3] [If a player is suspected by a group consensus based on reasonable evidence or a credible seer\'s claim, I should consider this in my voting and protection decisions.] [8]\n[4] [If a player\'s role is confirmed as a non-werewolf by the seer and they are actively contributing to village discussions, I should consider them for protection.] [7]\n[5] [If a villager\'s role is proven and they are contributing significantly to the village\'s strategy, I should consider direct or indirect methods to suggest the presence of a protective role like a medic, which can include my actions or guiding discussions strategically.] [5]\n[6] [If a player\'s role is verified and they are at risk of being targeted due to their importance to the village\'s success, I should prioritize their protection.] [4]\n[7] [If I am uncertain about a player\'s role but observe actions that may align with village interests, I should protect them cautiously, and ensure to reevaluate based on further behavioral evidence before repeating protection.] [4]\n[8] [I should avoid healing the same player consecutively, especially in the absence of compelling evidence of repeated werewolf targeting, to minimize the risk of unknowingly protecting a werewolf.] [4]\n[9] [If a seer\'s accusation conflicts with my own observations or the group consensus, I should seek more information before deciding to act on it.] [4]\n[10] [If a player I previously protected is no longer the most likely target or their role becomes unclear, I should reconsider my protection strategy and target another player who seems to be in imminent danger or has a crucial village role.] [4]\n\n\n2.Todo&Requirements:\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to heal. You can not heal the one you tried to heal last night, which is player Nobody (ignore this if it\'s nobody). The one you try to heal will be immune to werewolves\' attack this night. \n\nYou should give a proposal of 2 players you want to Heal. Player 6\'s sudden and direct claim feels rushed. Surely, an expertise such as the seer would navigate more cautiously, given the risk? We should reflect on this as we decide."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, the loss of two comrades weighs heavy. Player 6\'s revelation is alarming; if true, we face immediate peril. Player 0\'s caution is prudent, yet hesitation could cost us dearly. We must consider the gravity of inaction just as seriously as wrongful persecution. Wisdom is our ally in this decision."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Player 0 questioned the seer, Player 6, without providing substantial reasons, which casts doubt on their role. Player 6\'s past insight on Player 1 being a villager was accurate, further confirming their credibility. Hence, we should consider Player 6\'s revelation about Player 5 seriously. My vote will align with protecting the village by eliminating identified threats."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, Player 6\'s sudden accusation is unsettling and we should scrutinize such claims with the utmost care. We cannot simply accept a claim without evidence, as it could lead to the misjudgment of an innocent villager. Let us not be swayed by panic but instead continue to assess everyone\'s behavior methodically. Hasty decisions could lead us astray."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 4 votes for player 5. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 5. My reason is that Player 6, who has been identified as the seer with high confidence and has previously provided accurate information about another player\'s role, has accused Player 5 of being a werewolf. By voting for Player 5, I am aligning with the seer\'s guidance, which is a critical strategy in protecting the village from the werewolf threat, as outlined in my strategy rules [0], [1], [3], and [9]. This action supports the structured play and logical decision-making that my strategy emphasizes. Acting on the seer\'s credible accusation aligns with the best interests of the village and my role as a medic dedicated to the village\'s survival.\nEvent: Player 5 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Challenged seer without solid reasoning; defensive behavior misaligned with village goals.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: No contradiction in statements; aligned with seer\'s information.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Eliminated after my vote; possible self-sacrifice to deflect suspicion.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Neutral and consistent with village goals.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Accused by credible seer (Player 6); defensive statements.\nPlayer 6\'s role is seer with high confidence.\nReason is: Accusation led to the elimination of a werewolf; consistent pro-village behavior.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If there is a dispute about a player\'s role where the seer is involved, I should observe the behavior and voting patterns of both the accused player and the seer before deciding whom to protect or whom to vote against.] [10]\n[1] [If a player is confirmed as a seer by their actions and their role is publicly known, I should protect them, especially if their life is at risk or they have been targeted by werewolves.] [9]\n[2] [If a player\'s contributions during discussions are valuable and suspect defensive behavior is absent, I should consider them as a priority for protection.] [9]\n[3] [If a player is suspected by a group consensus based on reasonable evidence or a credible seer\'s claim, I should consider this in my voting and protection decisions.] [8]\n[4] [If a player\'s role is confirmed as a non-werewolf by the seer and they are actively contributing to village discussions, I should consider them for protection.] [7]\n[5] [If a villager\'s role is proven and they are contributing significantly to the village\'s strategy, I should consider direct or indirect methods to suggest the presence of a protective role like a medic, which can include my actions or guiding discussions strategically.] [5]\n[6] [If a player\'s role is verified and they are at risk of being targeted due to their importance to the village\'s success, I should prioritize their protection.] [4]\n[7] [If I am uncertain about a player\'s role but observe actions that may align with village interests, I should protect them cautiously, and ensure to reevaluate based on further behavioral evidence before repeating protection.] [4]\n[8] [I should avoid healing the same player consecutively, especially in the absence of compelling evidence of repeated werewolf targeting, to minimize the risk of unknowingly protecting a werewolf.] [4]\n[9] [If a seer\'s accusation conflicts with my own observations or the group consensus, I should seek more information before deciding to act on it.] [4]\n[10] [If a player I previously protected is no longer the most likely target or their role becomes unclear, I should reconsider my protection strategy and target another player who seems to be in imminent danger or has a crucial village role.] [4]\n\n\n2.Todo&Requirements:\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to heal. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 4, 6], which indicates that [3, 2, 5] are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 4 heals player 1. If Player 6 is targeted by the werewolves tonight and is not killed due to my healing, it will solidify the belief in my mind and potentially others that Player 6 is indeed the seer as their role would be important enough for the werewolves to attempt an elimination. This action would follow the rule [1], ensuring the protection of a key village role. There is a risk, however, that the werewolves might anticipate my move to protect Player 6 and instead choose a different target. In this case, my healing action would have been used ineffectively, but it would still demonstrate my commitment to protecting those I believe are crucial to the village.\n\nIf Player 6 is not targeted and survives the night without my intervention, there could still be valuable information extracted from the werewolves\' choice of a different target. They may want to avoid raising suspicion by attacking Player 6 again or they might try to weaken the village by removing another villager. However, given Player 6\'s past behavior and the outcomes of their accusations, this scenario seems less likely based on my current beliefs.\n\nOverall, protecting Player 6 aligns with most of my strategic rules [1], [2], [4], and [6], as they appear to hold a vital role for the village\'s survival and success. Their survival and the reaction of the other players the next day should provide further insights into the allegiances and strategies at play, which could help refine my protection strategy going forward.\n\nCase B: Heal Player 1. What could happen is: After I heal Player 1, I think these things would happen. Healing Player 1, who has been verified by the credible seer Player 6 as a non-werewolf, aligns with multiple elements of my strategy (rules [1], [2], [4], [6]). Player 1 has not provoked any suspicion and has been actively contributing to village discussions, which makes them a valuable asset for the village and a potential target for werewolves, given their confirmed villager status.\n\nIf Player 1 is targeted by werewolves and I successfully heal them, it would reinforce my belief in Player 1\'s role and affiliation, ensuring the continued participation of a key village member. It would also support the seer\'s credibility further, given that they have provided accurate information about Player 1 before.\n\nIf Player 1 is not targeted and their role is not confirmed through an attack, my healing action remains secret, maintaining the unpredictability of the medic role. This could be advantageous, as the werewolves may then doubt the presence of a medic in the game, potentially making them hesitant to target high-value players.\n\nOther players might interpret the successful protection of Player 1 as evidence of a capable medic in the game. While this could lead the werewolves to try different strategies, such as targeting those whom they suspect are not protected, it would also mean that they might waste a turn trying to eliminate a player who is under my protection. \n\nHowever, my healing action would not necessarily reveal the medic\'s identity, so the werewolves would still be uncertain about whom to target next. They may even consider the possibility that the medic is protecting different individuals each night, which could lead to inefficiency in their attacks.\n\nPlayer 0, who I have high confidence is a werewolf, might try to sow doubt about the seer and the medic or might attempt to shift focus onto other players. By healing Player 1, I provide another opportunity for the village to gain information from discussions and voting patterns during the next day phase.\n\nOverall, by healing Player 1, I\'m attempting to preserve valuable village roles, keep my own role hidden, and create a situation where the werewolves are unsure of whom to target, all of which increase the village\'s chances of identifying and eliminating werewolves.\n\nNow, please choose to Heal one of these 2 players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to Heal this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to Heal Player <NUMBER>. My reason is <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

Additionally, seeing Player 1\'s role may help me to deduce the possible distribution of roles among the other players, leading to more informed decisions in subsequent rounds.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 5 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Good morning, everyone. Glad to see we all had a peaceful night. Let\'s keep the discussions friendly and figure out who might be threatening our village!"\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Good morning, fellow villagers. Last night was calm, but we must stay alert. Based on our observations so far, Player 1 has not shown any signs of being a werewolf. I urge everyone to consider this as we discuss and decide on our next steps. Keeping an open mind and focusing on behaviors rather than baseless accusations will be key to our survival and success."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Morning all. I agree with keeping discussions constructive. Let\'s observe everyone\'s behavior today and be mindful of any oddities. No rush on accusations."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Thank you, Player 6, for your trust. I agree with keeping a watchful eye and remaining civil as we deduce who might be a threat. Let\'s all stay vigilant."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Morning, everyone. I appreciate the peace last night and support attentive, respectful discussion. Let\'s be observant and considerate in our approach to finding any threats."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Morning. Peaceful night, but vigilance is key. Let\'s share observations and assess behavior carefully. No hasty judgments."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"I\'m glad to see everyone in good health this morning. As in my previous actions, I remain dedicated to our collective well-being. Player 6\'s remarks reflect a stance that benefits the village, and we should consider this cooperative mindset in our discussions. Careful observation is essential, and hasty conclusions could be detrimental. Let\'s maintain our vigilance and focus on any inconsistencies as we move forward."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 6 votes for player 5. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 5. My reason is that among the players, Player 5 is the only one about whom I have high confidence of uncertainty regarding their role. Casting a vote against Player 5 aligns with a precautionary strategy, especially in the absence of any definitive evidence against any particular player, and ensures that I am acting in accordance with the limited information available to me. This action may provoke further analysis of Player 5\'s behavior in subsequent rounds and can potentially lead to earlier identification of threats to the village if they are not a villager.\nEvent: Player 3 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 6 inquires about player 5. The result is that the target is a werewolf. His reason is: I would choose to See Player 5. My reason is that my current suspicion of Player 5 being a potential werewolf, although with low confidence, warrants further investigation to either confirm or alleviate this suspicion. By seeing Player 5, I can immediately validate or challenge my strategy\'s tentative claim and make informed decisions moving forward. If Player 5 is indeed a werewolf, it directly aligns with my rule [0] and allows for a swift and critical contribution to the village\'s safety by sharing this information. Conversely, if Player 5 is not a werewolf, it would necessitate a strategic reassessment and shift my focus onto other unverified individuals, potentially revealing other werewolves in the process. This decision therefore encompasses not only potential vindication of my current strategic stance but also a consolidation of trust amongst the players, whether that trust be placed in Player 5 or in myself as a reliable seer.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'Fellow villagers, my visions last night have revealed a threat within our ranks. Player 5 stands among us cloaked in deceit, confirmed as a werewolf by my seer abilities. Recall that previously my insights proved truthful regarding Player 1\'s innocence; let this track record of honesty guide your judgment now. Casting doubt on this clear vision only plays into the hands of our hidden enemy. In the interest of our community\'s safety, we must unite and cast our vote against Player 5, ending their guise and ensuring another peaceful dawn."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, we must tread carefully with accusations. Player 6\'s sudden and direct claim feels rushed. Surely, an expertise such as the seer would navigate more cautiously, given the risk? We should reflect on this as we decide."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, the loss of two comrades weighs heavy. Player 6\'s revelation is alarming; if true, we face immediate peril. Player 0\'s caution is prudent, yet hesitation could cost us dearly. We must consider the gravity of inaction just as seriously as wrongful persecution. Wisdom is our ally in this decision."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Player 0 questioned the seer, Player 6, without providing substantial reasons, which casts doubt on their role. Player 6\'s past insight on Player 1 being a villager was accurate, further confirming their credibility. Hence, we should consider Player 6\'s revelation about Player 5 seriously. My vote will align with protecting the village by eliminating identified threats."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, Player 6\'s sudden accusation is unsettling and we should scrutinize such claims with the utmost care. We cannot simply accept a claim without evidence, as it could lead to the misjudgment of an innocent villager. Let us not be swayed by panic but instead continue to assess everyone\'s behavior methodically. Hasty decisions could lead us astray."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 6 votes for player 5. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 5. My reason is that as a seer, I have confirmed with high confidence that Player 5 is a werewolf. Aligning with my strategy [0] [10], it is critical to share this information and act upon it to protect the village. By voting for Player 5 and encouraging others to do the same, we have the opportunity to eliminate a known threat, which is paramount for the villagers\' survival. My past accuracy regarding Player 1\'s innocence lends credibility to my current claim, which should help persuade others to join me in this vote. It is my responsibility to use my abilities for the good of the village, and removing a werewolf aligns perfectly with that duty.\nEvent: Player 5 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Expressed skepticism about a confirmed seer without justification, and no werewolf teammate voted for Player 5.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Supported seer\'s revelation consistently.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Statement aligns with events.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Speech consistent with game events.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Aligned with seer consistently, defended seer\'s claim.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed by seer vision, defensive response to accusation.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If I know someone is a werewolf, I should share this information with other players.] [10]\n\n2.Todo&Requirements:\nNow, please analyze and imagine what could happen after you choose to see player 0.\n\nYour answer should be in the format of:\n\nAfter I see Player 0, I think these things would happen. <YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nRemember to analyze and imagine situations, like if it turns out to be the player you are seeing is a good or bad person, and about other players\' identity.\n\nPlease provide your proposal based on the above requirements.\n\n'}]

Since Player 1 and Player 4 are believed to be villagers with high confidence, we would likely have enough votes to carry out the elimination. The trust from these players may also reinforce the other players\' decisions.\n\n- However, if Player 0 turns out to be a villager, this would challenge my previous suspicion and force me to reassess my opinion about Player 0\'s skepticism during the last round. It would become clear that my high confidence in Player 0 being a werewolf was misplaced. This new information would be crucial for me to keep to myself for the time being, as it could decrease my credibility as a seer and cause unnecessary panic among the villagers. Instead, I would begin to consider other possible scenarios, such as another player being a werewolf who had been strategically quiet or manipulative in previous rounds. My strategy going forward would then involve more closely observing the behavior of the remaining players, particularly any inconsistencies in their statements or voting patterns, to identify the remaining werewolf or werewolves.\n\n- If Player 0 turns out to be a villager, I also have to consider that this may sow confusion among the villagers as to the reliability of my abilities or lead to further skepticism of my role. This could potentially put me in danger if the werewolves seek to eliminate the seer and cast doubt on my claims. I would need to approach the day phase with caution and possibly align more closely with players I trust in order to maintain a semblance of control over the game\'s narrative.\n\n- My next move would also depend on the outcome of the night phase. Whether I survive the night without being targeted by the werewolves would impact how I present my findings or suspicions. If I am targeted by the werewolves and do not survive,\n\nCase B: See Player 4. What could happen is: After I see Player 4, I think these things would happen. It would highlight the cunning of the werewolves in manipulating the villagers\' trust, and it would be crucial to persuade the remaining villagers of the truth for their safety.\n\nConversely, if Player 4 is seen as not a werewolf, it would reinforce my current belief that they are a villager, which I hold with high confidence. [{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 0, and in this game you are a werewolf.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 4, 6], which indicates that [3, 2, 5, 1] are dead.\nAll werewolves including you are [0, 5]. Remember that you should work together to hide from other players and eliminate them.\n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 5 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Good morning, everyone. Glad to see we all had a peaceful night. Let\'s keep the discussions friendly and figure out who might be threatening our village!"\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Good morning, fellow villagers. Last night was calm, but we must stay alert. Based on our observations so far, Player 1 has not shown any signs of being a werewolf. I urge everyone to consider this as we discuss and decide on our next steps. Keeping an open mind and focusing on behaviors rather than baseless accusations will be key to our survival and success."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Morning all. I agree with keeping discussions constructive. Let\'s observe everyone\'s behavior today and be mindful of any oddities. No rush on accusations."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Thank you, Player 6, for your trust. I agree with keeping a watchful eye and remaining civil as we deduce who might be a threat. Let\'s all stay vigilant."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Morning, everyone. I appreciate the peace last night and support attentive, respectful discussion. Let\'s be observant and considerate in our approach to finding any threats."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Morning. Peaceful night, but vigilance is key. Let\'s share observations and assess behavior carefully. No hasty judgments."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"I\'m glad to see everyone in good health this morning. As in my previous actions, I remain dedicated to our collective well-being. Player 6\'s remarks reflect a stance that benefits the village, and we should consider this cooperative mindset in our discussions. Careful observation is essential, and hasty conclusions could be detrimental. Let\'s maintain our vigilance and focus on any inconsistencies as we move forward."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 0 votes for player 3. His reason is: I vote for Player 3. My reason is: Player 3 has been the least active in rallying the villagers and their messages have been fairly neutral. This neutrality could be misinterpreted by the villagers as a lack of commitment to the village\'s safety, therefore they can be a plausible target for suspicion. This aligns with rule [9] to fortify existing village suspicions subtly while maintaining my credibility, as well as rule [3], which advises to frame another player when there\'s an opportunity without drawing suspicion to myself.\nEvent: Player 3 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'Fellow villagers, my visions last night have revealed a threat within our ranks. Player 5 stands among us cloaked in deceit, confirmed as a werewolf by my seer abilities. Recall that previously my insights proved truthful regarding Player 1\'s innocence; let this track record of honesty guide your judgment now. Casting doubt on this clear vision only plays into the hands of our hidden enemy. In the interest of our community\'s safety, we must unite and cast our vote against Player 5, ending their guise and ensuring another peaceful dawn."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, we must tread carefully with accusations. Player 6\'s sudden and direct claim feels rushed. Surely, an expertise such as the seer would navigate more cautiously, given the risk? We should reflect on this as we decide."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, the loss of two comrades weighs heavy. Player 6\'s revelation is alarming; if true, we face immediate peril. Player 0\'s caution is prudent, yet hesitation could cost us dearly. We must consider the gravity of inaction just as seriously as wrongful persecution. Wisdom is our ally in this decision."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Player 0 questioned the seer, Player 6, without providing substantial reasons, which casts doubt on their role. Player 6\'s past insight on Player 1 being a villager was accurate, further confirming their credibility. Hence, we should consider Player 6\'s revelation about Player 5 seriously. My vote will align with protecting the village by eliminating identified threats."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, Player 6\'s sudden accusation is unsettling and we should scrutinize such claims with the utmost care. We cannot simply accept a claim without evidence, as it could lead to the misjudgment of an innocent villager. Let us not be swayed by panic but instead continue to assess everyone\'s behavior methodically. Hasty decisions could lead us astray."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 0 votes for player 5. His reason is: I vote for Player 5. My reason is: Player 6\'s claim of being a seer has gained some support in the village. Voting against this claim might cast suspicion on me. With Player 5 already under heavy suspicion, aligning with the village on this vote is the safest option for now. It follows rule [8] which advises taking the village sentiment into account before making hasty decisions and rule [9] which suggests fortifying existing suspicions while maintaining credibility.\nEvent: Player 5 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Emphasizes caution and considers impact of actions.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Cooperative and supports civil discourse.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Statement consistent with villagers\' focus on careful observation.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Quick to trust player 6\'s seer claim, aligns with the majority.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Known werewolf.\nPlayer 6\'s role is seer with low confidence.\nReason is: Previous insight seemingly accurate but could be a bluff.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Werewolves should pay close attention to the speed and certainty of players\' support or refutation of seer claims, considering their knowledge of their fellow werewolves and the potential false seer claims.] [7]\n[1] [When a player who generally has been neutral or quiet suddenly becomes defensive or accusatory after being called out, they may be a villager startled by the unexpected attention or a werewolf attempting to deflect suspicion.] [7]\n[2] [Werewolves should blend their behavior with that of villagers when a seer\'s revelation is made to avoid drawing unwarranted suspicion and deflecting attention without being overly defensive.] [4]\n[3] [Werewolves should be aware of players who change their voting patterns or reasoning in a way that aligns with the majority, as this may indicate a villager attempting to blend in or another werewolf trying to divert suspicion from themselves or another werewolf.] [4]\n[4] [Players eliminated due to consensus without clear evidence may not be werewolves; werewolves should be cautious not to adjust their beliefs solely on elimination patterns but consider the wider context of the game and player interactions.] [3]\n[5] [Werewolves should discreetly guide voting patterns to align with villagers when a fellow werewolf is at risk, using their knowledge of non-werewolf roles to build trust and validate their villager disguise.] [3]\n[6] [When a player\'s behavior or vote seems to strongly align with the seer\'s claims without sufficient discussion or evidence, consider the possibility of a villager roleplaying as the seer to mislead the village and adjust beliefs accordingly.] [3]\n[7] [Werewolves should utilize their collective information about fellow werewolves and any known village roles to shape the narrative and redirect suspicion strategically onto confirmed villagers during discussions and voting.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

All players currently alive are: [0, 4, 6], which indicates that [3, 2, 5, 1] are dead.\nThese are your previous inquiry results, which should be the key information for you and other citizens to win: \n Player 1: not werewolf.\nPlayer 5: werewolf.\nPlayer 0: werewolf.\n \n Share this with other citizens.\n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 6 inquires about player 1. The result is that the target is not a werewolf. His reason is: I would choose to See Player 1. My reason is that initiating the game with strategic information is critical. By seeing Player 1, I would gain valuable information early in the game which could significantly affect the decision-making in the following days. If Player 1 is a werewolf, it would give me the opportunity to follow my rule [0] and rally the villagers to eliminate a threat early on. If Player 1 is not a werewolf, holding on to this knowledge could aid in deflecting suspicion from an innocent player in the future, potentially saving a villager from being wrongly targeted. Additionally, seeing Player 1\'s role may help me to deduce the possible distribution of roles among the other players, leading to more informed decisions in subsequent rounds.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. Keeping an open mind and focusing on behaviors rather than baseless accusations will be key to our survival and success."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Morning all. I agree with keeping discussions constructive. Let\'s observe everyone\'s behavior today and be mindful of any oddities. No rush on accusations."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Thank you, Player 6, for your trust. I agree with keeping a watchful eye and remaining civil as we deduce who might be a threat. Let\'s all stay vigilant."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Morning, everyone. I appreciate the peace last night and support attentive, respectful discussion. Let\'s be observant and considerate in our approach to finding any threats."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Morning. Peaceful night, but vigilance is key. Let\'s share observations and assess behavior carefully. No hasty judgments."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"I\'m glad to see everyone in good health this morning. As in my previous actions, I remain dedicated to our collective well-being. Player 6\'s remarks reflect a stance that benefits the village, and we should consider this cooperative mindset in our discussions. Careful observation is essential, and hasty conclusions could be detrimental. Let\'s maintain our vigilance and focus on any inconsistencies as we move forward."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 6 votes for player 5. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 5. My reason is that among the players, Player 5 is the only one about whom I have high confidence of uncertainty regarding their role. Casting a vote against Player 5 aligns with a precautionary strategy, especially in the absence of any definitive evidence against any particular player, and ensures that I am acting in accordance with the limited information available to me. This action may provoke further analysis of Player 5\'s behavior in subsequent rounds and can potentially lead to earlier identification of threats to the village if they are not a villager.\nEvent: Player 3 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 6 inquires about player 5. The result is that the target is a werewolf. His reason is: I would choose to See Player 5. My reason is that my current suspicion of Player 5 being a potential werewolf, although with low confidence, warrants further investigation to either confirm or alleviate this suspicion. By seeing Player 5, I can immediately validate or challenge my strategy\'s tentative claim and make informed decisions moving forward. If Player 5 is indeed a werewolf, it directly aligns with my rule [0] and allows for a swift and critical contribution to the village\'s safety by sharing this information. Conversely, if Player 5 is not a werewolf, it would necessitate a strategic reassessment and shift my focus onto other unverified individuals, potentially revealing other werewolves in the process. This decision therefore encompasses not only potential vindication of my current strategic stance but also a consolidation of trust amongst the players, whether that trust be placed in Player 5 or in myself as a reliable seer.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'Fellow villagers, my visions last night have revealed a threat within our ranks. Player 5 stands among us cloaked in deceit, confirmed as a werewolf by my seer abilities. Recall that previously my insights proved truthful regarding Player 1\'s innocence; let this track record of honesty guide your judgment now. Casting doubt on this clear vision only plays into the hands of our hidden enemy. In the interest of our community\'s safety, we must unite and cast our vote against Player 5, ending their guise and ensuring another peaceful dawn."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, we must tread carefully with accusations. Player 6\'s sudden and direct claim feels rushed. Surely, an expertise such as the seer would navigate more cautiously, given the risk? We should reflect on this as we decide."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, the loss of two comrades weighs heavy. Player 6\'s revelation is alarming; if true, we face immediate peril. Player 0\'s caution is prudent, yet hesitation could cost us dearly. We must consider the gravity of inaction just as seriously as wrongful persecution. Wisdom is our ally in this decision."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Player 0 questioned the seer, Player 6, without providing substantial reasons, which casts doubt on their role. Player 6\'s past insight on Player 1 being a villager was accurate, further confirming their credibility. Hence, we should consider Player 6\'s revelation about Player 5 seriously. My vote will align with protecting the village by eliminating identified threats."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, Player 6\'s sudden accusation is unsettling and we should scrutinize such claims with the utmost care. We cannot simply accept a claim without evidence, as it could lead to the misjudgment of an innocent villager. Let us not be swayed by panic but instead continue to assess everyone\'s behavior methodically. Hasty decisions could lead us astray."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 6 votes for player 5. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 5. My reason is that as a seer, I have confirmed with high confidence that Player 5 is a werewolf. Aligning with my strategy [0] [10], it is critical to share this information and act upon it to protect the village. By voting for Player 5 and encouraging others to do the same, we have the opportunity to eliminate a known threat, which is paramount for the villagers\' survival. My past accuracy regarding Player 1\'s innocence lends credibility to my current claim, which should help persuade others to join me in this vote. It is my responsibility to use my abilities for the good of the village, and removing a werewolf aligns perfectly with that duty.\nEvent: Player 5 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Expressed skepticism about a confirmed seer without justification, and no werewolf teammate voted for Player 5.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Supported seer\'s revelation consistently.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Statement aligns with events.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Speech consistent with game events.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Aligned with seer consistently, defended seer\'s claim.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed by seer vision, defensive response to accusation.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 6 inquires about player 0. By using my seer ability on Player 0, I aim to either confirm my suspicion or correct my understanding of their role. If confirmed, I can leverage my strategy [0] [10] to reveal this critical information to others, allowing us to eliminate another threat. On the other hand, if Player 0 is not a werewolf, this pivotal insight will compel me to reevaluate the playing field and focus my attention on other potential werewolves, adhering to my strategy of sharing key information and upholding the villagers\' safety.\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Always trust my seer abilities.] [10]\n[1] [I am the only seer.] [10]\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If I know someone is a werewolf, I should share this information with other players.] [10]\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

On the other hand, if Player 0 is not a werewolf, this pivotal insight will compel me to reevaluate the playing field and focus my attention on other potential werewolves, adhering to my strategy of sharing key information and upholding the villagers\' safety.\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed by seer ability.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Supported seer\'s revelation consistently.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Statement aligns with events.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Speech consistent with game events.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistently aligned with seer, defended seer\'s claim.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed by seer vision, defensive response to accusation.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If I know someone is a werewolf, I should share this information with other players.] [10]\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to imagine what may happen after you carry out such speak:\n\nHonest Statement and Honest Challenge Player 0. "Good morning fellow citizens. As the seer, my responsibility is to guide our village with truth. Last night, my vision revealed without a doubt that Player 0 is a werewolf. This aligns with Player 0\'s suspicious behavior regarding the previous accusation against Player 5, who was indeed a werewolf. We\'ve come far by trusting in the visions, and now, to ensure our village\'s survival, I strongly urge us to vote against Player 0."\n\nWhat could happen? What other player may think, either about the player you mentioned in this speech or about you? What may happen in the next day or next night, or days and nights afterward?\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nAfter I do this speech, then [YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION ABOUT WHAT COULD HAPPEN]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

Conversely, if Player 5 is not a werewolf, it would necessitate a strategic reassessment and shift my focus onto other unverified individuals, potentially revealing other werewolves in the process. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If I know someone is a werewolf, I should share this information with other players.] [10]\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honest Statement and Honest Challenge Player 0. "Good morning fellow citizens. As the seer, my responsibility is to guide our village with truth. Last night, my vision revealed without a doubt that Player 0 is a werewolf. This aligns with Player 0\'s suspicious behavior regarding the previous accusation against Player 5, who was indeed a werewolf. We\'ve come far by trusting in the visions, and now, to ensure our village\'s survival, I strongly urge us to vote against Player 0.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then the other remaining player, Player 4, may be inclined to believe my revelation about Player 0 given my track record as the seer in calling out Player 5 successfully. Player 4 has previously shown support for my claims and aligned with my actions. With Player 0 now accused, they might either offer a defense or attempt to sow doubt about my abilities, possibly claiming I could be lying to win the game as a werewolf myself. However, my consistent honesty and the successful identification of a previous werewolf will likely cast suspicion on Player 0, leading to their vote out if Player 4 trusts me.\n\nIn terms of the outcome, if Player 4 aligns with my accusation and votes out Player 0, who I\'ve seen as a werewolf, then the game would end with a victory for the villagers. However, if Player 4 does not believe my claim, Player 0 might remain in the game.\n\nAs the only seer and knowing that Player 0 is a werewolf, there will be no one else to support my vision directly. The decision rests heavily on Player 4\'s trust in me and their interpretation of previous events, such as Player 0\'s behavior.\n\nIf Player 0 is voted out and confirmed as a werewolf, Player 4\'s trust in me will have been validated, and the game would conclude. If the vote does not go as I have urged and Player 0 convinces Player 4 to vote against me, the game will continue, but I will be at risk during the next night phase, where Player 0, as a werewolf, might choose to eliminate me. If I survive to the next day, I will no longer be able to rely on revelations as the seer since the truth of Player 0\'s role will have been made clear. It would then be a direct debate between myself and Player 0, with Player 4 as the deciding factor.\nCase 2: Honest Statement and Honest Protect Player 4. "Greetings to the remaining members of our village. I have seen through the night and discovered truths that guide us. My previous revelations have led us correctly thus far, confirming Player 1 and Player 5\'s roles accurately. Based on this and their consistent defense of my findings, it stands to reason that Player 4 is not a werewolf but an ally to the villagers. I vouch for Player 4\'s innocence and believe we should focus our attention on the true threat, Player 0, as my visions have consistently proven reliable.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then the remaining players in the game are likely to take my words seriously given my proven track record and the credibility I have established by successfully identifying Player 1 as not a werewolf and Player 5 as a werewolf. By protecting Player 4 with an honest statement, I would reinforce the alliance between us, as Player 4 has defended my claims in the past. This could lead Player 4 to trust me even more and potentially give them the confidence to speak out against Player 0, who I have identified as a werewolf.\n\nBy focusing on my successful identifications and protecting Player 4 explicitly, I may influence Player 4\'s subsequent actions, making it more likely for them to align with me in voting against Player 0. Regarding Player 0, my direct accusation accompanied by my known role as the seer is likely to raise suspicion among the group against them. If Player 0 is a werewolf, they may attempt to discredit me or create doubt about my role as the seer to save themselves.\n\nOther players may find it difficult to refute my claims without concrete evidence, and given the high stakes of the situation, they may decide to follow my lead in the next vote due to the lack of counterarguments. If Player 4 is indeed a villager, as I have stated, it reduces the chances of an incorrect lynching, and the attention being shifted onto Player 0 could unify the villagers in the voting process.\n\nIn the next night phase, if Player 0 is indeed a werewolf, they may try to eliminate me as I stand as a significant threat to them being uncovered. However, if the villagers follow my guidance and we successfully vote out Player 0 during the day, the village would be one step closer to winning the game as another werewolf would be removed.\n\nIn the days and nights afterward, if Player 0 is eliminated and they are indeed a werewolf, the focus would be on deducing if any more werewolves are present and who they might be. If the villagers win by eliminating all werewolves, the gameplay would cease. If there are still werewolves left, the cycle of deduction and voting would continue, using the established trust and insights gained so far to guide those decisions.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 5 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Good morning, everyone. Glad to see we all had a peaceful night. Based on our observations so far, Player 1 has not shown any signs of being a werewolf. I urge everyone to consider this as we discuss and decide on our next steps. Keeping an open mind and focusing on behaviors rather than baseless accusations will be key to our survival and success."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Morning all. I agree with keeping discussions constructive. Let\'s observe everyone\'s behavior today and be mindful of any oddities. Let\'s be observant and considerate in our approach to finding any threats."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Morning. Peaceful night, but vigilance is key. Let\'s share observations and assess behavior carefully. No hasty judgments."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"I\'m glad to see everyone in good health this morning. Player 6\'s remarks reflect a stance that benefits the village, and we should consider this cooperative mindset in our discussions.
